The era of modern anaesthesia in Germany began on January 24th, 1847.	3.091944468432957
This day, professor in ordinary Johann Ferdinand Heyfelder anaesthetized a patient with sulphuric ether in the clinic of surgery and ophthalmology of the University of Erlangen.	3.5646499161647998
By March 17th, 1847, Heyfelder had performed 121 surgical procedures under ether.	3.0890865230605717
The operations in majority were teeth-extractions, and a few more complex operations such as the treatment of a harelip or of lip cancer or the resection of the shoulder joint.	4.13622624283976
This monograph published in March, 1847, represents one of the first complete dissertations on sulphuric ether in the German literature.	3.3751732570185875
In a special chapter he analyzed the development of various physiological and psychological parameters during etherization.	3.543725576326332
Heyfelder also examined blood and urine of some etherized patients and reported that he did not find any important or specific alterations.	3.1276937480298193
In 1847, Heyfelder was probably the first to apply salt-ether in man.	3.3692990967995233
After 4 administrations he concluded that salt ether acted more quickly but shorter than sulphuric ether.	2.636537435475698
Advantageous were its application without problems and ease of induction.	3.5368147330271724
Disadvantageous were its high volatility, its price and the difficulty of getting it in a pure form.	3.152026386804801
From December, 1847, on Heyfelder started to use chloroform.	3.1701764296157133
He was now able to perform more major operations, for example the total resection of the hip-joint.	4.0833102801442305
In his book The experiments with sulphuric ether, salt ether, and chloroform he describes a great number of anaesthetic administrations using these 3 agents.	2.8307576274670496
In his summary Heyfelder concluded, that chloroform was undoubtly superior to sulphuric ether mainly because it was a quicker acting and longer lasting agent and leads to deeper narcosis.	2.829333264101604
Moreover its application was much easier for it needed no special apparatus.	3.143982779403374
However, because of its great anaesthetic potency, Heyfelder particularly demanded great caution in the application of chloroform.	3.2184924834926085
Explicitely he expected an assistant for chloroformizations, whose only duty was to supervise the inhalations and the patient - a forerunner of the modern specialized anaesthesiologist.	3.168481696469821
Background: To evaluate the publication rate of abstracts presented during the German Anaesthesia Congress (DAK) in MEDLINE-listed journals in comparison to the publication rate of abstracts presented during the meeting of the European Society of Anaesthesiologists (ESA).	2.5619510800251395
The uniform development of the human embryo, as described by classic human embryology, has been confirmed by sonoembryological studies.	4.219831258246016
In particular, the embryonic brain is suitable for transvaginal ultrasound examination, because the large "cystic" cavities of the brain can easily be imaged.	3.554619775812624
Sonoembryology not only describes normal embryonic anatomy and normal relations and proportions of organs, but also the development of structural abnormalities.	4.266542205784617
Approximately one-third of all congenital anomalies, originate from the central nervous system (CNS).	2.88720901403165
Based on normal sonoembryology and on recent experiences with early CNS anomalies, we recognize some sonographic signs of an early CNS anomaly: (1) Apparent dysmorphology of the brain or the head; (2) Altered appearance of the cerebral ventricles with disproportion of the brain compartments, where the amount of fluid is either greater or less than normal; (3) In the early fetal period, choroid plexuses that are too small to fill the ventricle from the medial to the lateral wall; (4) Irregular contour of the spine/back; (5) Extra-CNS anomalies.	3.693698906525057
In the following survey, normal sonoembryology of the CNS is described, and CNS anomalies of the early pregnancy are discussed.	3.44127129653062
Telomerase is an enzyme that elongates telomeric repeats, the specialized structures at the ends of chromosomes that provide genomic stability and compensate for the physiologic process of telomere shortening.	2.757666898666696
It has been implicated in cellular senescence, immortalization, and carcinogenesis.	2.946724086242894
Over 85% of human tumours, and 95% of non-melanocytic skin cancers, show telomerase activity, in contrast to the corresponding normal tissues.	3.782327822583175
This suggests that telomerase activity may play an important role in carcinogenesis.	3.0461512272112388
Recent evidence shows that telomerase is active not only in embryonal and germ line tissues, but also in some normal tissues.	3.3461754349538455
In the skin, this activity has been traced to the stem-cell-bearing epidermal basal cell layer, possibly reflecting the presence of telomerase-competent stem cells.	3.5312461938334323
These findings require a reconsideration of our interpretation of telomerase activity in tumours of the skin and other tissues.	3.4451193791276715
As a causal relationship linking telomerase activity and cancer has yet not been demonstrated, some caution is warranted.	2.945884067499998
The established criteria of auditory brainstem responses (ABR) such as JV latency, JI-V interpeak latency and interaural differences of  latency or amplitude have been found to be sensitive for detecting tumors of the cerebellopontine angle if a response is present.	3.131402421000592
However, the ABR can be absent in cases of acoustic neuromas because of desynchronization, even though pure-one audiometry indicates that responses should be present.	3.151517635248214
This retrospective study compared the ABR and pure-tone thresholds in 234 cases with cerebellopontine angle tumors and a control group of 181 cases with sensory hearing losses in order to quantify threshold discrepancies.	3.4615475336783885
The average deficit of the objective ABR threshold (DOABRT) to the subjective pure-tone threshold for those frequencies between 1-6 kHz was 3.6 dB for the control group (ABR and pure tone thresholds very close) and 31.2 dB for the tumor group (ABR threshold much higher than the pure-tone threshold).	3.317268122442293
ABR thresholds 30 dB higher than the high-frequency pure tone thresholds were found in 40.6% of the tumor group and in none of the control group.	4.533846586452714
Thus, deficits of the ABR threshold >30 dB can be considered to be an additional criterion for detecting retrocochlear disease and increases ABR sensitivity for tumor detection even if responses are absent.	3.5015545122609786

To date, at least 12 types of primary dystonia can be distinguished on a genetic basis.	3.5835488007484098
A 3-bp deletion in the DYT1 gene causes early onset, generalized torsion dystonia (TD), and mutations in the GTP cyclohydrolase I and the tyrosine hydroxylase genes result in dopa-responsive dystonia (DYT5).	2.982963676177423
A missense change in the D2 dopamine receptor in one large family (DYT11) has recently been implicated in myoclonus-dystonia.	3.176035170047482
Furthermore, seven other loci for dystonia genes have been mapped to chromosomal regions, including a locus for a mixed dystonia phenotype (DYT6), one form of focal dystonia (DYT7), three types of paroxysmal dystonia (DYT8-10), X-linked dystonia-parkinsonism (DYT3), and rapid-onset dystonia-parkinsonism (DYT12).	3.156752856407106
No positive linkage results have yet been obtained for autosomal recessive TD (DYT2) and several other families of different types of dominantly inherited TD (DYT4).	3.028499624319682
In addition, hereditary secondary dystonia may occur as part of familial diseases of the basal ganglia, metabolic and storage disorders, and various X-linked and other familial neurodegenerative syndromes affecting the basal ganglia.	3.2850988831534256
It may be anticipated that the traditional clinical and etiological classifications of dystonia will increasingly be replaced by a genetic one and that the identification of more dystonia genes may lead to a better understanding of these largely nondegenerative disorders.	3.345985058064352

We conclude that in the mid-term, a combination of psychoeducational and cognitively oriented therapy for patients and their keypersons can improve the course of schizophrenic illness.	3.937978225026234

Post exposure prophylaxis (PEP), defined as treatment of a person who has been exposed to an HIV infected person by a route through which transmission is possible, is one possible way to decrease the number of new cases.	3.685513900908827
Economic evaluation can help to answer the question whether PEP should be provided to different exposed populations or whether the resources that would be used for PEP should be used for other HIV prevention or treatment interventions.The value of PEP depends both on the costs and effectiveness of the intervention.	3.63420513929405

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is the strongest ligament of the human knee joint.	4.321414488961664
Its origin is at the lateral wall of the medial femoral condyle and the insertion is located in the posterior part of the intercondylar area.	4.917746504767686
The posterior cruciate ligament consists of multiple small fiber bundles.	2.9451560809586534
From a functional point of view, one can differentiate fiber bundles with an anterior origin and fiber bundles with a posterior origin at the femur.	3.147534368796494
The anterior fibers insert in the anterolateral part of the tibial insertion zone.	3.2813894295929287
These fibers become tense when the knee is flexed.	2.4911075121139494
The posterior fibers insert in the posteromedial part of the tibial insertion and become tense when the knee is extended.	2.9300892565555503
The main part of the posterior cruciate ligament consists of type I collagen positive dense connective tissue.	3.5295821453413616
The longitudinal fibrils of type I collagen are divided into small bundles by thin type III collagen positive fibrils.	3.013475613016851
In this region, the structure of the tissue resembles fibrocartilage.	3.8302329042863743
Oval-shaped cells surrounded by a metachromatic extracellular matrix lie between the longitudinal collagen fibrils.	3.1513399045398787
The femoral origin and the tibial insertion have the structure of chondral apophyseal enthesis.	3.499626906675757
Near the anchoring region at the femur and tibia there should be various mechanoreceptors which might have an important function for the kinematics of the knee joint.	3.4104517100860505
The blood supply of the PCL arises from the middle geniculate artery.	3.109539603975347
From the synovial sheath, the blood vessels penetrate the ligament in a transverse direction and anastomose with a longitudinally orientated intraligamentous network.	3.0348462790767026
The distribution of blood vessels within the PCL is not homogeneous.	2.8326140757304183
We detected three avascular areas within the ligament: Both fibrocartilaginous entheses of the PCL are devoid of blood vessels.	2.891231916216029
A third avascular zone is located in the central zone of fibrocartilage of the middle third region.	3.5164384114536995

From July 1993 to December 1997, temporary transesophageal pacing was used to convert 29 tachycardia episodes in 19 patients.	3.2924371137782202
At the time of the first tachycardia episode, patients' ages were 1 month to 26 years (mean 9.8 yrs).	3.280406995839169
Onset was within the first 2 weeks postoperatively in 6 patients and occurred later in 13 patients (1 to 19 years after operation).	3.871788923332801
Postoperative pacemaker implantation had been performed in 2 pts; 17 of 19 pts were receiving antiarrhythmic medication.	3.5234176159986403

Atrial cycle length of tachycardia ranged from 160-380 ms with 1:1 to 4:1 AV conduction.	3.0438589503234863
Temporary transesophageal pacing was performed following an algorithm starting with 4 extrastimuli (20 ms below atrial cycle length of tachycardia).	2.93659863493693
Tachycardia terminated in 27 of 29 cases (93%) without complications.	3.5083549667606304
In 3 cases, conversion was achieved by pacing after amiodarone 5 mg/kg i.v.	3.1537483259394787
After tachycardia conversion, sinus- or pacemaker rhythm was present in 20 cases.	3.4503145173783345
In 9 cases atrial fibrillation was recorded; spontaneous conversion to sinus rhythm occurred after a maximum of 3 min (7 cases) or persisted and required direct current cardioversion (2 cases).	3.3295659181443886

10 mm in diameter), was not adequate to the aiming process.	3.770882061335781

These measurements showed a relatively constant distance between the upper distal transverse hole and the anterior aspect of the tibia (average 12.3 mm and only a narrow range (7.6 mm).	2.9246552878408485
These data were the basis for the development of an aiming technique that exploits the relatively constant distance between the distal nail hole and the anterior aspect of the tibia.	3.1895885460721756

Age differences were obtained for neuroticism, extraversion, openness, and agreeableness.	3.1858839432967603

In a population of healthy women with uncomplicated pregnancies, the prevalence of perinatal mortality or morbidity is so low that even with meta-analysis of several studies the numbers remain too small to show significant differences for these rare events.	3.229529540810251
In high-risk cases the routine application of fetal heart rate monitoring throughout labor and delivery is undisputed and leads to a significant drop in morbiditiy and mortality of the baby.	3.5248899143798504
With careful selection of pregnant women a combination of electronic fetal heart rate monitoring and auscultation during certain segments of the first stage of labor provides adequate surveillance.	3.4933205110324543

Epileptic seizures may alter autonomic functions.	3.382478334664179
This is especially the case with complex focal seizures (of temporal lobe origin) and grand mal.	3.1022853779639665
Most frequently, such seizures cause ictal tachycardia, sometimes tachypnea, probably caused by the propagation of epileptic discharges to autonomic cerebral structures.	2.9706352463641688
Ictal bradycardia and asystole are rare phenomena.	3.3432807715292525
However, they may be life threatening.	3.911897307070741
Their differentiation from primary cardiac arrest is possible by the use of ictal EEG and ECG registration.	3.7898473784699407
Postictal serum prolactin measurement does not differentiate syncope from seizure.	3.074098856131968
However, a postictal increase of creatine kinase is only measured after epileptic seizures and not after syncope.	2.6886596527942186
Treatment of such epileptic seizures includes an optimization of anticonvulsant drug therapy and the implantation of a cardiac demand stimulator.	3.3474372953176035

From January 1987 to December 1990, a total of 49,054 emergency calls were registered using a standardised protocol.	3.244845754269475

CPR was initiated in the remaining 224 patients, who comprise the study population (defined as 100%).	3.7542672566457194
All patients who were admitted to a hospital were followed using a second protocol.	3.7821911699534363

In 156 (69.6%) cases resuscitative attempts were unsuccessful in the field.	3.2868262405511093
Survival has to be regarded as an individual fate; the overall results are discouraging.	3.848253896718247
Even though this study analyses the largest population of posttraumatic CPR ever published, prognostic factors could not be identified due to the few survivors.	3.6649690902000507

Intraarticular bleeding and muscle bleeding occur spontaneously or as a result of trauma in hemophilia A or B.	3.589446403407036
The most common sites for hemarthrosis are the knees joints, elbows and ankles joints.	2.78803073243894
Resorption of intraarticular blood induces reactive hemophilic synovitis.	3.1894908131969886
Hyperplasia of the synovium can be followed by recurrent bleedings.	3.895848984719176
These early reactions can change to a chronic synovitis and cause cartilage damage, finally resulting in a complete destruction of the joint.	3.708778355808132
Since 1981 158 adults and 61 children with a hemophilia A or B were treated at the Center for hemophilic disorders Frankfurt in an interdisciplinary approach.	3.162753133466637
Consequent prophylactic treatment with factor substitution can prevent the incidence of severe hemarthrosis.	3.8945740534670032
Minor joint bleedings are treated by adequate factor substitution, temporarily non-weight bearing of the extremity, application of ice-packs and physical therapy.	3.454481748970832
More severe joint hemorrhages should be aspirated in order to reduce the acute synovitis.	4.131677644788324
This is followed by a consequent physical therapy (joint and soft tissue techniques) and anti-inflammatory drugs.	3.1629868252745803
The goal is a sufficient muscular balance of the joint, the improvement of the coordination, and the proprioception.	5.021767914662408
The chronic synovitis is less painful and poorly responses to conservative interventions.	3.114063111616542
Local ice application, sytemic and local anti-inflammatory treatment support the physical therapy.	3.2542529757891
Soft heel shock absorber, elastic and semi-rigid bandages prevent recurrent bleeding episodes by shock absorption and decrease of synovial impingement.	2.6981179891858056
Synovectomy is indicated in cases of chronic persistent synovitis.	4.563086007343243
Radiosynoviorthesis (RSO), which is an alternative in certain cases, has been performed with great success in 12 cases in our hospital.	4.606622989624643

A 72-year-old patient received 0.1 mg morphine by the intrathecal route and 2x1.5 mg midazolam as adjuvant therapy.	3.2346461376464024
Severe respiratory depression and somnolence supervened 3.5 h later, which lasted over the next 24 h and necessitated intubation and mechanical ventilation.	3.2276563059503935
Continuous administration of >6 mg naloxone to antagonize the supposed effect of the morphine had no effect.	3.1573002895945064
The patient's condition was not normalized until a single dose of 0.3 mg flumazenil was administered.	3.020780768386245
For the time being, especially in the case of elderly patients, we recommend that strict indications are adhered to when intrathecal administration of morphine is considered and that less than 0.1 mg morphine is given.	3.7478003059783087
Respiration should be monitored for quite some time.	3.753626749023362
In contrast to the often debated NYHA classification, the determination of peak oxygen uptake (peak VO2) by cardiopulmonary exercise testing allows an objective assessment of the exercise capacity of patients with congestive heart failure (CHF).	3.3854660473362044
However, cardiopulmonary exercise testing is a time consuming and costly diagnostic tool, which requires sophisticated equipment and specially trained personell.	3.2509949007115355
Exercise capacity can also be determined by the 6 minute walk test.	3.9879806482970745
This test simply measures the distance covered by strong walking on a hallway level within 6 minutes.	3.078373415648833
The 6 minute walk test is a submaximal exercise test, which is associated with much smaller increments in heart rate, blood pressure and plasma catecholamines than cardiopulmonary exercise testing.	3.6595099283596806
It is characterized by a very small intraindividual variance.	3.132605239301154
Furthermore, it can be easily performed and, due to low logistic and personal requirements, it is very cost effective.	4.363102085185099
The results of the 6 minute walk test - as well as of cardiopulmonary exercise testing - are influenced by extracardial exercise-limiting disorders, such as pulmonary diseases.	3.359039908949344
Independent from the etiology of CHF, the results of the 6 minute walk test are closely related to peak VO2.	3.6183242711603536
In serial exercise testing the distance covered within 6 minutes allow to predict the individual peak VO2.	3.3425265924408283
Like peak VO2 the 6 minute walk test has been shown to be a predictor of morbidity and mortality in CHF, with its predictive value being independent from left ventricular ejection fraction and other potential prognostic parameters.	3.46575204842342
In CHF patients a walking distance < 300 m is associated with a one-year-mortality of up to 50%, whereas the one-year-mortality in patients reaching a walking distance > 450 m amounts to only a few percent.	4.454062403451698
In addition, the hospitalization rate of patients reaching a walking distance of < 300 m is several fold higher than in those with a walking distance >= 450 m. Like cardiopulmonary exercise testing, the 6 minute walk test allows to control the efficiency of specific treatments and to monitor the natural course of the disease.	3.1135683987036127
The 6 minute walk test is, thus, a cost effective alternative to cardiopulmonary exercise testing in CHF patients.	3.351171568581384
However, neither the 6 minute walk test alone nor the results of cardiopulmonary exercise testing alone are sufficient for selecting patients, e.g., for cardiac transplantation, as each individual case requires a synopsis of all relevant facts and parameters.	3.3755994085349625
We report the first case of prurigo pigmentosa in the German literature.	3.1948671111813343
For over a year, a 16-year old white girl developed an immensely pruritic symmetrical reticular, papulo-vesicular eruption on the trunk, axillae and pubic region.	3.1119121707810944

The effects of glycerol are discussed in detail.	2.8836243299573874
Glycerol can lead to a transition of crystalline lipid structures within the horny layer lipids into liquid crystalline states.	3.27507475758125
Especially if applied in oil/water-emulsions it improves, the hydration of the horny layers better than urea.	3.007684814312327
In addition, if facilitates the dissolution of desmosomes within the superior layers of the horny layer enhancing desquamation.	2.781947137931485
Furthermore, by using glycerol, the mechanical properties of the skin can be influenced; long term used leads to increased elasticity.	3.5764873027176876
The roughness of the horny layer is reduced, which can be explained by the abrasive and/or the hydrating effect.	3.8717965797180423
Glycerol used in o/w-emulsions also protects against the influence of tensides or noxious lipophilic agents.	3.0680700169511907
Presumably a flux from the base of the epidermis towards its surface triggers the regeneration of the barrier.	3.442970289896694
Finally,  glycerol can lead - similarly to urea - to an improvement in active agent penetration, as has been proven for hexylnicotinate.	3.3334539232757083

Facial trauma is frequent and mainly caused by motor vehicle accidents.	3.1312458740713645
Due to this main etiologic factor, trauma to the facial skeleton is often associated with serious injuries, commonly involving the brain, chest or abdomen.	3.1046509664826902
As a consequence, the initial clinical management of these patients includes control of hemorrhage and immediate assessment of life-threatening injuries, including the maintenance of the airways.	4.057623242337444
Patients presenting with facial trauma are initially evaluated with a systematic clinical examination because many fractures can be accurately diagnosed by inspection and palpation alone.	2.8896806338749785
In these cases plain film radiographs serve only for confirmation and documentation of the diagnosis.	3.116522970558957
In many other cases accompanying and extensive soft tissue swelling may clinically obscure fractures.	2.8445089801576593
A complete and accurate evaluation of these patients requires additional radiological imaging methods.	3.439685422705464
A series of plain films may be generally sufficient but in most of the cases they can be regarded as initial screening methods for more thorough diagnosis with computed tomography (CT).	3.805972643671037
In trauma patients CT is the imaging method of choice because it shows more fracture lines and displaced fragments than any other imaging modality.	3.3109357621642133
CT delineates soft tissue and bony structures and can localize and even characterize foreign bodies.	3.305018583103803
A complete and accurate characterization of the fracture type and potentially associated complications is mandatory for the appropriate treatment and can only be achieved by careful radiological (CT) evaluation.	3.8803935809242613

Metastasis formation is a multistep process that requires tumor cells to progress through many different stages.	3.3366055091818736
One of the first steps is a disturbance of the epithelial integrity through a decrease in intercellular homotypic adhesion.	3.7068368142319303
Proteolysis of the extracellular matrix, as well as increased locomotion, leads to intravasation and dissemination of the tumor cells.	4.5267666511362155
In the target organs metastasizing cells adhere to the endothelium, extravasate and form metastases.	2.787548338575101
Finally, neoangiogenesis is required for the initiation as well as the growth of the metastases, providing the tumor cells with both nutritive agents and growth factors.	4.0264825672452895

Type I and type II diabetes are the most common types of diabetes.	4.102595957755787
The ratio of type I to type II diabetes is about 1:9.	3.9274946753279694
Type I diabetes is caused by an absolute insulin deficiency and is therefore referred to as insulin-dependent diabetes.The disease becomes manifest clinically in childhood or adolescence ("juvenile diabetes"), although manifestation in adulthood is being increasingly observed.	3.375443205205171
Morphologically, a subtotal ( > 80 %) to total loss of beta cells in the pancreatic islets occurs.	3.505256767275768
Lymphocytic insulitis, which disappears after the beta cells have been totally destroyed, is pathognomonic of type I diabetes.	3.2547399078368446
This insulitis is an expression of an autoimmune event that is triggered by a multitude of factors.	3.5213278898848444
An important factor appears to be a genetic predisposition (HLA DR3/DR4/DQ8) in connection with as yet unknown environmental factors (e. g., viruses).	3.2704169914381214
Autoantibodies, such as islet cell cytoplasmic antibodies (ICA), insulin autoantibodies (IAA), and/or autoantibodies to the GABA-synthesizing enzyme glutamic acid carboxylase (GAD), are already detectable in a prediabetic phase, although it is not possible to predict the time of clinical manifestion.	3.9416389497670896
The course of the disease is dependent on age.	3.821687201505556
Young children require insulin therapy sooner than juveniles or adults.	2.93009128183714
This article summarizes data from recent studies on the prevalence, diagnosis and therapy of the obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) in children.	3.962954725705307
The prevalence of this disorder in 4-6 year old children is 0.7%.	4.078104069999292
Leading clinical sign in 90% of patients is habitual snoring, but this is rather nonspecific, as 60% of patients investigated for habitual snoring do not have OSAS.	3.674578615198811
Other signs such as daytime sleepiness, failure to thrive, profuse nocturnal sweating or mouth breathing are equally nonspecific.	2.830695617889894
The diagnosis, therefore, has to be confirmed by polysomnography, where OSAS is suggested by the occurrence of >5 obstructive apneas/hypopneas per hour of sleep in conjunction with a CO2 of >50 mmHg for >8% of sleep time and/or >1 desaturation to <=90%/h.	3.9174834160799947

The operative realignment of mechanical axis deviations (MAD) is necessary to prevent early joint degeneration and to reach normal load-bearing.	3.4012887439755586
Modern types of external fixation systems allow an alignment of the mechanical axis to exact degrees.	3.336738206143348
Predominantly this are corrections of angular deformities.	3.344689093561122
In some cases the analysis of the MAD does not show any angular deformity, but a parallel staggering of the mechanical axis lines of a bone.	3.4619484122534883
Such parallel staggering of the mechanical axis lines is defined as a translation deformity of the bone.	3.1930733526721853
In combined deformities with angulation and translation the centre of deformity can be established proximal or distal out of the limit of the bone.	3.5422507304072366
In translation deformities the realignment of the mechanical axis requires a parallel re-staggering made by a translation-osteotomy or by a counterangulated double osteotomy.	3.009107969907693
In complex deformities with angulation and translation, the translation requires a separate corrective planning.	2.784422815562366
By using external fixator systems to perform acute or progressive corrective osteotomies the position of the Axis of Correction of Angulation (ACA) in relation to the n-CORA of the deformity has to be considered.	3.0291808687305775
If ACA position is not conform with the n-CORA position relevant geometric effects in relation of length and translation occur.	2.931010687227237
These geometric effects to corrective osteotomies can be calculated by using simple trigonometric formulas or graphical methods.	2.862644130889791

The syndrome is characterised by fever, an itchy erythema with edema, confluent papules and purpura of the hands and feet in a "gloves and socks" distribution.	3.0545401353965467

On rare occasions, malunited clavicular fractures are associated with a pattern of disability that includes not only pain but also functional or neurovascular impairment.	3.197609153042629
In these cases, clavicular osteotomy and correction of the deformity should be considered.	2.9977266842692427
In four patients with a malunited fracture of the clavicle following nonoperative treatment, we performed a clavicular osteotomy for deformity.	4.009462868648261
In all four patients the clavicular fracture healed with shortening associated with pain and ipsilateral glenohumeral dysfunction.	2.9081032122661963
The deformity was not associated with neurovascular dysfunction.	3.248938057338292
In preoperative X-ray studies, the shortening of the malunited clavicle was between 0.9 and 2.2 cm in comparison to the contralateral clavicle.	3.7630293233680754
All patients underwent an extension osteotomy of the clavicle with interposition of an autogenous iliac crest bone graft.	3.3775328297893625
The follow-up was 1 - 4 years postoperatively.	3.700483527997623
The functional outcome was evaluated using the Constant-Murley and the UCLA score.	3.3736022179558285
All patients had immediate pain relief following osteotomy and correction of the deformity.	3.0548181902563796
The shoulder function rapidly improved, and the functional outcome was good in three out of the four patients.	4.5491272700439245
If there is associated functional impairment in malunited clavicular fractures, extension osteotomy combined with autogenous bone grafting may produce predictably good results.	2.7838998763968297

Necrotizing pancreatitis is still associated with considerable morbidity and mortality.	3.3602622651806855
Formerly, surgical treatment with early and extensive pancreatic resection has been the standard.	4.520993990505205
Improvements in our understanding of the pathogenesis of the disease and progress in the field of intensive care therapy have made conservative therapy the initial standard in the treatment of necrotizing pancreatitis.	4.541066242442705
A considerable percentage of patients with sterile necrosis can be managed with low morbidity and mortality by conservative treatment without operation.	4.398475414078769
Nevertheless, surgical treatment is indicated in patients with infected necrosis and in sterile necrosis if multiorgan failure persists over a limited period of time despite maximum intensive care therapy.	3.8569025650505475
Pancreatic resection should be abandoned for surgical treatment of pancreatic necrosis, as results with regard to morbidity, mortality and long-term outcome are unsatisfactory.	4.1811945766773135
Today the surgical standard is careful digital necrosectomy, which must be followed by either postoperatve drainage, repeated open lavage or continuous closed lavage.	2.9493439398392787
In experienced hands, all three procedures provide similar results with regard to morbidity and mortality.	3.496020896795025
The aim of quality management in rheumatology is to improve care and outcome in patients with rheumatic diseases.	4.155348672077306
This can be achieved by means of prospective long-term observation of the patient with regular documentation of clinical, radiological, biochemical and functional data using certain validated scoring methods (DAS, radiological score, ADL score Hanover or Health assessment questionnaire, SF36, etc.).	3.4359464553386374
Long-term observation and documentation including radiographs have been performed in the rheumatology hospital in Ratingen for 20 years without even knowing the term quality management.	3.087995026962222
Quality management in a hospital for rheumatic diseases begins with certain structural prerequisites: possibility of direct admission of a patient to the hospital by the family physician, outpatient clinic to investigate and to follow patients over a long period of time, multidisciplinary team with specialists in rheumatology, orthopedic surgery, physiotherapy, ergotherapy, special care, psychological, and social services, close cooperation with specialists in neurology, dermatology, ophthalmology, etc., department of radiology, special laboratory, facilities for internal diagnostics and treatment.	3.2652477611099195
The hospital needs a training program for the qualification of rheumatologists and orthopaedic surgeons.	2.85747825683742
The hospital staff should closely cooperate with the doctors in private practice who admit patients and should continously support patient organizations.	2.9932318456298868
The quality of outcome is influenced by the process quality which depends on the following factors: selection, training and motivation of the hospital staff; supervision of clinical assessment and documentation by senior physicians, daily x-ray demonstrations and case reports, interdisciplinary case demonstrations at least every week in addition to daily consultation, team reports, regular education including review of actual literature for physicians, education programs exchanging knowledge with physiotherapists and nurses, and regular education programs for patients.	3.269969324744422
Process quality can only be achieved by an interdisciplinary approach and regular communication between all participants including the patient, whose opinion must be noted and regarded.	3.8157768315625726
As far as possible, the same doctor who treats the patient in the hospital should follow her/him in the outpatient clinic.	3.67723878364428
The quality of outcome can be improved by regular reinvestigation of the patient with control of medication, side effects, efficacy, documentation of clinical, biochemical, radiological, and functional data.	3.685647592897305
Decisions for further treatment have to be based on these follow-up data.	5.107514399577676
A standardized follow up and documentation system for all rheumatology units with prompt feedback could definitely improve the quality of rheumatologic care in Germany.	3.1472155325237896

There is controversy about the amount and relevance of postoperative CO2 resorption.	3.221410275959915

Studies exist on the course of end-expiratory CO2 (PeCO2) alone over a longer postoperative period of time in extubated patients during spontaneous breathing.	3.7004310326716827
The goal of this prospective study was to investigate the amount of CO2 resorbed from the abdominal cavity in the postoperative period by means of CO2 metabolism.	3.720197991565762
After giving informed consent to the study, which was approved by the local ethics committee, 20 patients underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy.	4.418067795111059
All patients received general endotracheal anaesthesia.	2.8785931727209593
After induction, total IV anaesthesia was maintained using fentanyl, propofol, and atracurium.	3.0657672272100105
Patients were ventilated with oxygen in air (FiO2 0.4).	3.0897222207309776
The intraabdominal pressure during the surgical procedure ranged from 12 to 14 mm Hg.	3.5461034323971092
Thirty minutes after releasing the capnoperitoneum (KP), CO2 elimination (V.CO2), oxygen uptake (V.O2), and respiratory quotient (RQ) were measured every minute for 1 h by indirect calorimetry using the metabolic monitor Deltatrac according to the principle of Canopy.	3.402310655370191
Assuming an unchanged metabolism, the CO2 resorption (V.CO2) at any given time (t) can be calculated from V.CO2 (t)=V.CO2 (t)-RQ (preop) V.O2 (t).	3.478823037122652
It was thus necessary to define the patient's metabolism on the day of operation.	3.5633436795327658
The first data were collected before surgery and after introduction of the arterial and venous cannulae for a 15-min period.	3.7662005169190684
Measuring point 0 was determined after exsufflation of the KP and emptying of the remaining CO2 via manual compression by the surgeon at the end of surgery.	3.4550451890794704
Patient's tracheas were extubated and metabolic monitoring started 30 min after release of the KP for 60 min.	3.336932761117842
Simultaneously, a nasal side-stream capnometry probe was placed and the PeCO2 and respiratory frequency (RF) were obtained by the Capnomac Ultima (Datex) and registered every minute as well.	3.0412034660739895
Values were averaged over four periods of 15 min each.	3.2577106012315364
An arterial blood gas sample was drawn at the end of every 15-min period.	3.56859061157901
Postoperative pain was scored by a visual analog scale and completed by a subjective index questionnaire on general well-being.	3.2514031442558387
All data were analysed by the Friedman or Wilcoxon test; P<0.05 was considered significant.	2.853009482496733
The findings do not indicate CO2 resorption in the postoperative period after laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Tables 2 and 3, Fig.	3.4369751421491834
The postoperative RF was comparable to preoperative values.	3.389323510863093
Calculated CO2 was lower than 10 ml/min and within accuracy of measurements.	4.5078008812892385
The postoperative pain index ranged between 3 and 4, and 3.75 - 15 mg piritramid was administered.	3.0756838522241265
All patients feld tired immediately after the operation, but scores improved slightly at the end of the 60-min period of metabolic monitoring.	3.5443179786876686
There is no significant resorption of CO2 from the abdominal cavity later than 30 min after releasing the KP.	3.2849757301691294
Up to this time, any CO2 remaining in the abdominal cavity after careful emptying by the surgeon has been resorbed and exhaled.	3.2270982729463906

The clinical staging was correct in 75.0 %, high in 7.7 %, low in 17.3 %, the N-stages were correct in 59.2 %, high in 17.7 %, low in 23.1 %.	2.83359147248729
The sonographic staging was apparently superior with the T-classifications correct in 92.3 %, high in 7.7 %, low 0.0 %.	2.869374765240799

Standardized guidelines for exercise training for patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF) have not been established.	4.193967224919148
In the past CHF patients involved in exercise training studies demonstrated a wide range of cardiac and functional impairment, with an ejection fraction between 18 and 35% and a peak VO2 between 12.2 and 25.4 ml/kg/min on average.	3.3161036652155595
For determination of training intensity, a VO2 between 40 and 70% of peak VO2 and/or training heart rate between 60 and 80% of peak heart rate was used.	3.564537844078463
There was also a wide range for frequency (between 3 and 7 times per week) and duration of training (between 20 and 60 min per session).	3.454039320426855
For aerobic exercise training only continuous training methods were applied.	3.173293683577375
We have developed a new interval training method which allows intense exercise stimuli on peripheral muscles with minimal cardiac strain.	3.0031010504863085
After only three weeks of training, the improvement in aerobic capacity was similar to that reported after longer training periods using continuous methods.	3.2966460162502904
To determine work rate for work phases of interval training, a special steep ramp test was developed.	2.98501896460515
By analysis of acute physical responses to this testing procedure and to the interval training, both were proven to be tolerable in CHF patients, even if their ejection fraction is as low as 13%, or peak cardiac index not greater than 1.6 l/m2/min, and peak VO2 less than 8.5 ml/kg/min.	3.5248813158264256
Therapeutic choice in laryngeal carcinoma is influenced by the nature of the tumor and a variety of factors involving the patient and physician.	4.052835272227618
Small (T1) and exophytic (T1, T2) tumors are suitable for radiotherapy.	3.1132429433670734
Extensive tumors (large T2; T3) are treated by total laryngectomy or by primary irradiation, especially in the case of a good response to induction chemotherapy.	3.787355334097243
When radiation treatment fails, surgery succeeds in more than half of the cases.	3.254307790627883
Tumors infiltrating or transgressing the laryngeal framework (T4) can only be cured by total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy.	3.155133464762649
Subtotal or circular ablation of the adjacent pharynx or esophagectomy needs repair with visceral or myocutaneous grafts.	3.1103649277759953
Lymphatics are preferentially treated with the same modality as used in the primary disease.	4.912657538473706
Inconspicuous lymphatics should be treated electively in most cases, with the exception of early glottic cancer.	4.375989840867487
Induced hypotension is defined as a reduction in mean arterial blood pressure to 50-60 mm Hg in normotensive subjects.	4.17462042666773
The aim of induced hypotension is to decrease intraoperative blood loss, decrease the need for blood transfusions and improve operating conditions.	3.5810151346471253
Most studies indicate that induced hypotension can decrease intraoperative blood loss by 50% in many surgical procedures; however, some studies report that blood loss is not significantly reduced.	3.2123005862906346
Current methods of induced hypotension are based on the use of rapid and short-acting vasodilators as primary agents (nitroprusside, nitroglycerine, urapidil), supplemented by volatile anesthetics (isoflurane) and/or -blockers (esmolol) to improve effect, reduce dosage and prevent side effects (reflex tachycardia, tachyphylaxis, rebound hypertension).	3.4445901133540646
Major risks of induced hypotension are a reduction in blood flow (i.e.	3.955486394378701
ischaemia) of vital organs (brain, myocardium) and elevation of intracranial pressure in neurosurgical patients.	3.5230946147210433
Thus, major contraindications of induced hypotension are severe coronary artery disease, hypertension combined with arteriosclerosis of cerebral vessels and increased intracranial pressure in patients with cerebral disease.	3.631446984281576
Complications are rare in otherwise healthy patients, but may be higher in elderly patients and those with underlying organ dysfunction.	4.263774655629474
Therefore, careful assessment and selection of patients, together with consideration of the potential complications, appropriate choice of drugs and invasive beatby-beat monitoring, are essential for the safe practice of induced hypotension.	3.9674280877071353
Abstract  Empirical results stemming from infant research have contributed extensively to the understanding of coping with psychosocial stress and vulnerability for psychosomatic symptoms in later life.	2.968377374728589
The interaction and the emotional exchange between caregiver and child in the first months of life lead to representations of interactions that will be the base for the quality of attachment.	3.63835191125646
The mutual regulation of the caregiver-infant-pair enables the child to acquire a psychic capacity to regulate physiological requirements.	3.087335676446252
This selfregulatory function determines the potential of the later adult to react to distress - in a symbolic way using words or more in a somatic way by developing psychosomatic symptoms.	3.1426485831192266
First experiences with the treatment of psychosomatic patients with respect to the new findings about self-regulation are reported.	4.172253679025032
A 31-year-old pregnant woman had to undergo emergency abdominal surgery due to acute intestinal obstruction.	3.5681213119297244
The patient's preoperative history demonstrated multiple allergies as well as abdominal trauma several years before.	3.6809562892691403
The physical examination - including sonography of the two fetuses - showed no pathological signs.	3.5698753525346083
Anaesthesia was induced intravenously with the operating table tilted to the left side, using routine precautions pre-oxygenation, and rapid sequence intubation, and was maintained unproblematically.	3.379870161497946
About 20 min after the onset of surgery, hypotension, tachycardia, and a drop in oxygen saturation appeared.	4.484052430464206

The development of eyelid edema led to the diagnosis of an anaphylactic reaction.	3.7053677717283175

The suspicion of latex-related allergy was verified postoperatively by radio-allergen-sorbent test (RAST) and prick and scratch tests.	2.744910756510468
The mean arterial blood pressure is decreased during the first two trimesters of pregnancy and increases to preconceptional values during the last weeks of gestation.	3.9691169451887633
The heart rate increases during the whole course of pregnancy.	2.8650959579200586
During late gestation fewer patients show an increase in diastolic blood pressure and heart rate in the standing position.	3.6264376274017867
A fall in heart rate was only seen in this period.	3.7167349668033376
A fall in mean arterial blood pressure during standing is not related to the blood pressure in the supine position during the whole course of pregnancy.	3.2569361152960083
The hypotensive symptoms are twice as frequent during early pregnancy compared to late pregnancy.	3.053540105266516
Headaches, fatigue and cold extremities are the most usual complaints.	3.845568339257262
The frequency and intensity of these three symptoms decrease during gestation.	3.1782750657093883
Blood pressure in the supine position is reduced in symptomatic pregnant women.	3.202212801210602
However, the occurrence of these symptoms is not correlated to the fall in blood pressure in the standing position.	3.5269827407411425
The Birth-weight is not influenced by blood pressure in the supine position, but depends on the fall in blood pressure during standing.	3.430033607908503
Pregnant women with a more pronounced fall in blood pressure give birth to newborns with a lower birthweight.	3.3043992509445133
The combination of saltwater baths and subsequent ultraviolet irradiation is an effective treatment for psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.	2.9912128552040373
The aim of the present study was to determine the photosensitizing properties of two commercially available bath salts, original salt from the Dead Sea and sodium chloride.	2.491716089255492
To address this issue, test areas on the volar aspects of the forearms were soaked with salt solutions for 15 minutes prior to ultraviolet-B (UVB) irradiation.	3.005954241156423
The salt concentrations tested were 1%, 3% 5% and 15%.	3.5200769519884294
Tap water followed by UVB and UVB alone served as controls.	2.8145345266030737
Erythema was determined by visual and photometric measurement, and delayed tanning was assessed by colorimetry.	3.59677830126139
Erythema obtained by wetting the skin prior to UVB irradiation was more pronounced than erythema induced by UVB alone.	3.122711566851251
The most prominent erythema was yielded by tap water+UVB.	2.784906008583265
There was only a moderate influence on delayed tanning by bathing the skin prior to irradiation.	2.92517332814451
The results from the present study indicate that soaking the skin with salt solutions or tap water increases skin sensitivity to subsequent UVB irradiation.	3.466823463739985
This may contribute to the effectiveness of salt water baths followed by UV irradiation and may account for an increased sunburn risk after bathing.	3.48592405390397

Cor triatriatum dexter is a rare congenital malformation in which a membrane divides the right atrium into two chambers.	4.069482012445237
The membrane represents a persistence of the right sinus venosus valve (RSV).	3.449713809853378
Normally the RSV regresses between the 9th and 15th week of gestation, as the cephalic portion forms the crista terminalis and the caudal portion develops into the Eustachian and Thebesian valve.	2.8743568248838463
Any failure in the regression process may result in remnants of RSV as a simple muscle bar, a Chiari-network or a fenestrated or unfenestrated membrane (cor triatriatum dexter).	2.884692289749714
We describe a patient with cor triatriatum dexter in whom diagnosis was made several years after successful valvulotomy procedure for severe congenital valvular pulmonary stenosis.	2.913085230122487
Apoptosis and proliferation are important regulators of normal development and homeostasis in the bone marrow.	3.6546589510148637
Therefore, dynamics of hematopoiesis is mainly defined by these two parameters.	3.094347495408603
However, since only few data are available from previous studies, we performed a retrospective analysis to elucidate some aspects of this complex pathomechanism.	4.110825602540866
A total of 400 patients with chronic myeloproliferative disorders (CMPDs) and corresponding reactive bone marrow lesions were enrolled into this study.	2.9655542613280965
Apoptosis was detected in bone marrow tissue by the ISEL-technique and topoisomerase II  expression was demonstrated by the monoclonal antibody Ki-S1.	3.275681422870768
Furthermore, by determination of the proliferating-cell nuclear antigen labeling (PCNA) index, we were able to calculate the proportion of cells in the G2/M phase, because both nuclear antigens are expressed in different phases of the cell cycle.	3.316661041917845
Patients with IMF, PV, and ET revealed a normal range of apoptosis, whereas in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) a significant increase could be observed.	3.3745417853041193
On the other hand, IMF and PV were characterized by a raised proliferative activity.	2.727075234074016
Dynamics of hematopoiesis was assessed by calculation of the so called hematopoietic turnover index.	3.708010485292514
In CML and reactive lesions no alterations of this parameter were detectable, but IMF and PV showed a significant increase.	3.6474195926329265
Survival analysis disclosed a relevant worsening of life expectancy for patients with reduced apoptosis and proliferation.	3.85443508655082
In conclusion, our in-situ results confirm and extend previous experimental data on hematopoietic cell kinetics.	3.0420935595722542
In this context, a greater regenerative capacity of hematopoiesis may be reflected by an increased rate of apoptosis and/or proliferation and therefore is associated with a more favorable outcome.	3.7226688550672233

The studies were conducted initially using a lung simulator, and then in seven patients undergoing microlaryngeal surgery.	3.3021969913801623

The mean FiO2 was 0.74 +/- 0.1; the mean paO2 was 169.2 +/- 80.4 mm Hg; and the mean paCO2 was 40.9 +/- 2.4 mm Hg.	3.083067096001132
The mean airway pressure was 19 +/- 5.3 mm Hg prior to insertion of the endoscope and 12.3 +/- 6.9 mm Hg after insertion.	3.062685948774879
The mean positive end-expiratory pressure values increased from 2 +/- 0.6 to 3.6 +/- 2.3 mm Hg.	3.163320371770385
Reduction of the working pressure resulted in restoration of the initial inspiratory pressures and tidal volumes.	3.226936585294575

The rigidity of varicose veins was higher than that of normal veins; there was no difference between the varicose vein above a competent valve and the "normal" vein below this competent valve.	3.379105353618418
The matrix proteins demonstrated an increase in total fibres, whereas the elastic fibres were reduced and fragmented, explained the rigidity of varices.	3.756999636840422

A large number of G protein-linked receptors funnel extra-cellular signals as diverse as hormones, growth factors, neurotransmitters, and primary sensory stimuli through a set of G proteins to a small number of second-messenger systems.	3.0277465045062963
The G proteins act as molecular switches with an "on" and "off" state governed by a GTPase cycle.	2.9293570396717663
By virtue of its high affinity and specificity for guanine nucleotide binding and its intrinsic GTPase activity, the -subunit of the G protein (G) plays the critical role in regulation of the effectors by their corresponding G protein.	2.995244349979399
Mutations of G may result in either constitutive activation or loss of expression mutations.	3.3653423648124106
Given the variety of functions subserved by G protein-coupled signal transduction, it is not surprising that abnormalities in G protein-coupled pathways can lead to diseases with manifestations as dissimilar as blindness, hormone resistance, precocious puberty and neoplasia.	3.01779369278482
For a given defect in a G protein-coupled pathway, the extent of the manifestations will also be determined by the cellular distribution of the affected component.	3.7868928895423366
Defects in components expressed exclusively in a single cell type will cause more a focal disorder than defects in a widely expressed component, particularly in germline mutations (e.g., Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy), whereas somatic mutations of genes encoding even an ubiquitously expressed component can cause focal disease when the somatic mutation itself is focal (e.g., McCune-Albright syndrome).	2.908320838629577

The mechanisms of reperfusion injury following focal cerebral ischemia, however, are not known in detail.	3.6519750087508416
Recent studies strongly suggest that reactive oxygen species (ROS) and calcium overload play an important role in reperfusion injury and that pharmacological interventions against calcium- or free radical-mediated damage could extend the therapeutic window in cerebral ischemia/reperfusion.	2.8778907883088967

In Europe, mainly French, Belgian, English and Scandinavian researchers have been responsible for maintaining the methods.	2.704471047011594
In France, an entomological police laboratory has been set up in Rosny-sous-bois.	2.8597874098397753
In contrast to the United States of America where entomological evidence is accepted by the courts, the method has only just started to be accepted in Germany.	2.980418414839394
27 patients with sternocostoclavicular hyperostosis (SCC) and/or pustulotic arthroosteitis (PAO) were examined with whole body scintigraphy, conventional radiography, and other imaging modalities, such as CT, MRI.	4.1199602086030715
25 of 27 patients with SCCH showed a characteristic high bullhorn-like uptake of the sternocostoclavicular region with the manubrium sterni representing the skull and the inflamed sternocostoclavicular joints corresponding to the horns (=bullhorn-sign).	2.799973194150819
Scintigraphy revealed additional skeletal manifestations (spondylitis, sacroiliitis, osteitis, periostitis) in 19 of the 27 patients with SCCH and/or PAO.	3.3690335451293603
In combination with PPP or psoriasis pustulosa, the typical scintigraphic bullhorn pattern enables the diagnosis of PAO (19 patients) with high confidence.	3.5225335827586077
Patients with SCCH but without skin disease at the time of presentation (8 of 27 patients) may develop PPP later and, therefore, it is justified to classify them as incomplete PAO with high risk to develop other skeletal manifestations later in the course of the disease.	3.4702796486966654
PADAM stands for partial androgen deficiency in the aging male, and it is currently diagnosed with a testosterone level below 3 ng/ml (300 ng/dl or 12 nmol/l), and with symptoms varying according to the individual.	3.8555434894493468
The symptoms are a reduction or even loss of libido, a decline in muscle mass and strength, enhancement of visceral fatty tissue-padding, dryness of the skin, apathy, tiredness and distortion of mood right up to depression, and ostalgia due to osteoporosis.	3.0571367403628114

Upon immunohistochemical and ultrastructural studies, the number of melanocytes appeared normal.	4.000057014941391
The elongated dendritic processes of the melanocytes contained many mature melanosomes.	3.079631157576532
In the adjacent keratinocytes large melanosomes did not aggregate into complexes.	2.780889873208808
The diagnosis of localized reticulate pigmentary disorder was established.	2.923923212359047

Genital or flexural pigmented lesions have to be differentiated from melanosis of the vulva or acanthosis nigricans.	3.342094548625485

Methods: We report our experience in the diagnosis and surgical treatment of 12 patients with these tumors.	5.011390227866988
Results: Between October 1993 and December 1998, 41 patients with cystic tumors of the pancreas underwent surgical resection; in 12 cases (11 women, 1 man) a serous cystadenoma (10 micrcocystic, 2 oligomacrocystic) was found.	3.4001054183165165
Only 6 (50 %) patients had symptoms.	3.7339617943164853
The mean tumor size was 4.8 (2.7-10) cm.	3.303374518688827
Ultrasound, CT and MRT usually could detect the mass, but differentiation with other cystic lesions was not reliable.	3.452882255808572
All tumors were resected: 4 Whipple procedures, 7 distal pancreatectomies and 1 segmental resection were performed.	2.882677703998632
No patient died after surgery and none had to be reoperated on.	3.7105215400986755

We examined the prevalence of HIV-associated cutaneous disorders as well as the frequency and efficiency of UV-radiation in HIV-infected patients by evaluating the clinical records of 1310 patients seen between and 1994 and 1996.	3.7451743092297196
41 patients were treated with UVB-radiation and 4 patients with UVA1-radiation, while three patients received PUVA-therapy.	3.814358056058257
UV-radiation proved to be efficient and safe in the treatment of pruritic papular eruption, atopic dermatitis and psoriasis.	3.702802546302838
The staff at interventional radiological procedures is exposed to high levels of ionizing radiation.	3.2013722202600072
This applies especially to measures at cardiac catheterization laboratories.	3.0731205944052418
In this study the annual radiation exposure to the staff was estimated by measuring the dose rate under characteristic conditions.	2.997567939043051
It could be shown that the resulting radiation exposure was strongly dependent on the radiation protection measures and is also dependent on the operation conditions of the x-ray tube.	3.7214331837366577
The effective dose for the physician wearing a lead apron and thyroid shield was detremined to about 1.7 mSva.	2.7629775300925608
Without a thyroid shield an effective dose of about 3.5 mSva resulted.	3.1995976162028503
This corresponds to approximately the natural background radiation of about 2.4 mSva in the Federal Republic of Germany.	2.8867033811703924
Further, it could be shown that the readings of the film badges, usually worn by the staff, underestimate the effective dose by approximately a factor of two.	3.014340185370304
This is because the film badges do not include the contribution of the unshielded parts of the body to effective dose.	3.112495011930309
From the estimated annual effective dose, a lifetime dose of 68 mSv was estimated for a 40-year working career.	2.97510063307785
The corresponding lifetime risk for induced fatal cancer due to radiation exposure was determined to 0.3% applying the ICRP risk factor of 4  -  10-2 Sv-1.	3.2343558842985374
Considering the NCRP recommendations for a safe occupation, working in a cardiac catheterization laboratory can be considered as safe when applying all radiation protection measures.	3.4373475732813876
However, changing the protection measures and modifying the parameters of the x-ray-tube can lead to strong changes of the radiation exposure and the resulting risk estimation.	4.017262494927176
Treatment of pulmonary hypertension is an important issue in intensive care.	4.132349258400473
One therapeutic regimen involves the intravenous administration of prostacyclin (PGI2).	2.997546579000493
This, however, is accompanied by diminished hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction, reduced arterial oxygenation, and systemic vasodilation.	3.8330305647995107
Thus, its clinical usefulness is limited.	3.395846354963702
However, the inhalation of vasodilators such as nitric oxide (NO) or nebulized PGI2 causes a selective pulmonary vasodilation in ventilated alveoli and improved gas exchange, without any systemic vasodilation.	2.661551439664737
It has therefore gained importance for the treatment of pulmonary failure associated with high shunt fractions.	4.171597055567724
However, the inhalation of vasodilators may have adverse effects: in the case of NO, toxic side effects are predominant (MetHb, NOx), whereas in the case of PGI2, technical problems in terms of dosing and administration safety are of major interest.	3.672963187815711
Furthermore, some patients do not respond to the treatment.	3.6200422033418835
In some individuals a reduction in pulmonary hypertension can be seen, while others lack even pulmonary vasodilation.	3.7116519537819888
The exact pathophysiological mechanisms remain to be investigated.	3.2795342728094385
The treatment of infrarenal aortic aneurysms by means of transluminally placed endovascular prostheses reflects significant progress in the field of vascular surgery.	3.294091361075691
In the case of infrarenal aortic aneurysm it is possible to achieve technically successful implantation of such a prosthesis in well over 90 % of cases.	3.533641864510067
The rate of clinical success, meaning lasting effective exclusion of the aortic aneurysm, cannot (yet) be definitively determined, since no long-term results are so far available.	3.396047702284543
Secondary leaks are observed in at least 10 % of all patients, making a further therapy necessary (endorepair, conversion, embolization).	4.026490308658933
Further development of endovascular prostheses will include optimization of the aortal/iliac attachment of the prostheses, a better configuration and the development of long-lasting materials that can be used for endovascular prostheses.	4.081250973688676
The frequency of postspinal headaches after accidental puncture of the subarachnoid space with 16 - 18 G Tuohy needles is reported at 59 - 85%.	2.8068088831706874
A case of postspinal headache syndrome persisting over a period of 6 weeks following epidural anaesthesia during labour is described.	2.8668298470604094
A 30-year-old women had severe postspinal headache for 6 weeks after epidural anaesthesia during labour.	3.578618424114996
Intracranial haematoma and other abnormal processes were excluded by CCT.	3.3779857651780354
A pathologic EEG was not confirmed by cranial MRT.	3.1747617661004757
A lumbar epidural blood patch of 15 ml of autologous blood was performed at L3/4.	3.865645856523852
The patient stayed in bed for 12 h. After 3 h free of pain the patient complained of recurring headache.	3.268331273148677
After a further 48 h of bedrest she had recovered.	3.080195031982142
Because of lumbar pain 4 days after the epidural blood patch a MRT was performed, which showed the blood at L4 to S3 in the epidural space.	3.730725851802636
The diagnosis of a cerebrospinal fluid leakage was based on the history and the main symptom of postspinal headache: the pain onset in the supine position.	3.7432512920780985
Such possible treatments as diminishing subarachnoidal pressure by bedrest, increasing cerebrospinal fluid production by infusions, increasing epidural pressure by epidural infusions and closing the cerebrospinal fluid leakage by epidural blood patch are discussed.	2.8604582639911245
The average success rate with the epidural blood patch is 93%.	3.258502388923891
Volumes ranging from 5 to 20 ml are discussed for the autologous blood.	3.4291660686380134
We were able to document the position of the blood patch as L4 to S3 on MR tomography (the injection site was L3/4).	3.3827234862771935
Most patients are free of headache 1 h after epidural blood patch.	3.294247227064974
The blood patch alone was not immediately sufficient to prevent all further cerebrospinal fluid leakage.	3.129596465608529
Probably more than one subarachnoidal puncture had been made during the difficult epidural anesthetic procedure.	3.5431970077084305
On the other hand, the leak was probably only diminished because of the blood patch descending down to the wide sacral space.	3.165097531345085
The combination of the large-volume blood patch, which diminished the leakage, and conservative treatment, which narrowed the transdural pressure difference, was successful: the 6-week postspinal headache was cured.	3.208321331468111
Prolonged postspinal headache should be treated by epidural blood patch.	3.465031277875127
Careful monitoring for side effects is necessary with blood volumes larger than 10 ml.	3.3918809835990698
If there is no immediate relief, conservative therapy with 24 - 48 h of bedrest is recommended.	3.307643127118056
If the headache persists a second blood patch should be performed, with the volume and the probable caudal spreading of the first taken into account.	4.056321159004536

This grading approach is influenced by the subjective interpretation of the pathologist, especially concerning the weighting of criteria (scant, moderate, pronounced).	3.264576745061131
An observer-independent approach seems to be feasible by abandoning the concept of parameter weighting in favor of an binary approach noting only the presence or absence of these structure parameters.	3.290748992139438

Nasopharyngeal carcinomas (NPC) belong to the most frequent malignant tumours in certain parts of the world, e. g., south-east Asia, while they occur infrequently in western  Europe.	3.41068299426177
The association of NPCs with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a transforming human herpes virus, is well established.	2.9950742567365336
The current WHO classification recognises two major NPC histotypes, non-keratinising NPC and squamous cell NPC.	3.158712038879532
EBV is invariably present in non-keratinising NPCs and the viral oncoprotein LMP-1 (latent membrane protein-1) is expressed in some cases.	3.9111275877685237
The tumour cells of non-keratinising NPCs show phenotypic features which are inducible by LMP-1 in  vitro.	3.075503030523236
These may contribute to the development of the lymphoid stroma which is characteristic of this tumour type.	3.8467432235312136
Furthermore, the virus is detectable in nasopharyngeal carcinoma in situ.	2.6783133201610756
Thus, the virus is likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of  non-keratinising NPCs.	3.9167430485082906
By contrast, the association of squamous cell NPCs with EBV  displays a geographical variability.	3.40274290368357
It appears, therefore, that squamous cell NPCs are a heterogenous group of tumours distinct from non-keratinising NPCs.	3.14121186705504

The median overall survival time was 81 month, the 5- and 10-year survival rates were 54% and 31%, respectively.	3.482364673165899
The median time to progression was 56 months, while the 5- and 10-year progression-free survival rates were 45% and 24%.	3.2647716250496566
Univariate analyses identified the total radiotherapy dose (p = 0.01), duration of symptoms (p = 0.05), the presence of seizures (p = 0.04), and the CT pattern following intravenous contrast (p = 0.005) as significant prognostic factors for overall survival.	4.283240260858645

Hence, in a prospective comparative clinical trial started in 1989 we have treated 45 male diabetics suffering from DNPU with the same daily doses of netilmycin, administered either in systemic venous infusions (SVI: n=21, three times/day) or in RVP (n=24, once/day).	3.5057040879709582
After 10 consecutive days of treatment, ulcers had closed in 8 of the 24 patients treated with RVP, as against 3 of the 21 treated with SVI.	3.6904131592242027
Diminution of the ulcer area by >30% including full debridement was achieved in 10/24 of the RVP cases (SVI: 4/21).	3.4816505334478345
During 6 months of follow-up, amputation of toes or forefoot was necessary in only 1 patient in the RVP group, but in 4 in the SVI group.	4.1237032974448535
Partial restitution of osteolytic damage was observed in some cases after RVP.	4.104744076727828
Our results show that regional netilmycin therapy given by the RVP procedure is clearly superior to equal netilmycin doses administered by SVI for the treatment of DNPU.	3.187022138819706

There is hardly any other discipline that illustrates the conflict between the freedom of science and research, that is to say, ultimately, what is medically possible, and human dignity and the protection of life or, in other words, what can be justified in ethical or legal terms, so clearly as reproduction medicine.	3.0838144515769406
The topics involved in this conflict cover a broad spectrum, ranging from in vitro fertilization with subsequent implantation of the embryo through the problems of multiple pregnancy and selective feticide, the many questions raised by assisted fertilization, and especially by anonymous sperm donation, and the controversial techniques of preimplantation diagnosis and cryopreservation, to the legal aspects of prenatal diagnosis, some of which have already been the subjects of cases decided in the supreme courts.	3.510586255338799

In MR-imaging, similar to computed tomography, diagnosis of metastatic lymph-node disease is based on lymph-node sizes, and thereby it is non-specific.	4.325127895257737
Superparamagnetic iron oxide as a potential contrast medium for MR-lymphography accumulate in normal lymph node tissue after endolymphatic, interstitial and, in case of very small particles, after intravenous injection.	3.4730691186939824
No accumulation occures in lymph node metastases.	3.5922009465996236
Lymph-node metastases can be detected by all three injection techniques.	3.800301066835531
It has been shown experimentally, that in particular small metastases can be detected in normal sized lymph nodes.	3.5843650981833894

All optically active molecules have at least one asymmetric atom in common which is attached to four ligands, that can have different three dimensional positions.	3.22304583121245
Therefore it can be concluded that the resulting isomers are chemically identical in all respects except for the direction with which they rotate plane-polarized light.	3.0927254091912637
When the isomer and its corresponding enantiomer are present in equal proportions, they are called racemic mixture, a mixture that does not rotate polarized light, since the optical activities of the two isomers cancel each other.	3.213859500440286
Although the isomers are chemically identical other optically active molecules can interact with these isomers in a geometrically specific way termed stereoselectivity.	2.7026732661286537
The human body comprises a chiral environment due to optically active proteins; thus it is not surprising that enantiomeric drugs exhibit different pharmacological properties, when used as pure optical isomers.	2.9115761020505047
Till today most modern anaesthetics have been optical isomers, which are mainly used as racemic mixture (1:1 mixture).	3.461572171399031
For financial reasons pure isomers were only used for research purposes, but nowadays the wide clinical use of pure isomers is financially feasible due to new production techniques.	2.9129951046554976
The terms eutomer and distomer were chosen to indicate the more or less potent form of the drug.	3.5540950701122758
The clinical use of pure isomers is only of advisable, if there are significant differences between eutomer and distomer in desired or side effects.	3.0146598272485945
Among the modern anaesthetics ketamine, isoflurane, bupivacaine and atracurium exhibit an asymmetric carbon.	2.8990623752150118
For most drugs the separation in pure isomers will reduce side effects.	2.9105823276459852
For volatile anaesthetics this question is still unanswered, since experimental and clinical results are inconsistent so far.	3.3720208612867113

Our study aimed at obtaining further evidence of hereditary factors in this disease.	3.1601706740223925
We included 33 unselected patients from 28 families with aspirin intolerance and rhinosinusitis in this study.	2.9244159391239672
Controls were recruited from individuals treated in our ENT clinic for diseases other than aspirin intolerance (n=52).	3.1690648890623176
The application of a tryptophan-free amino acid mixture (tryptophan depletion test) induces a rapid and substantial lowering of both total and free plasma tryptophan.	3.1203369940302377
Consequently, the brain serotonin content and also cerebral serotonin function are decreased.	3.140779909610231
This method provides a paradigm to study the role of serotonin in the pathobiology of depressive disorders and their treatment modalities.	3.349070761033259
Untreated depressed patients show few behavioral effects during tryptophan depletion.	3.059972690378951
In depressed patients during an antidepressant or light-therapy-induced stable remission, a transient depressive relapse was induced by tryptophan depletion.	3.135623581636768
Healthy subjects with a genetic risk for affective disorder show worsening of their condition induced by tryptophan depletion.	3.112297521093616
These findings indicate the relevance of altered brain serotonin function in the pathophysiology of affective disorders and strengthen the importance of serotonin in the mechanism of action of antidepressants.	3.7081665075937456
Since recently published studies revealed some evidence that the serotonergic system is directly involved in the pathophysiology of various psychiatric syndromes besides depression, it seems to be reasonable to evaluate the validity of the tryptophan depletion test also in non-depressed patients.	3.952881491801916
Several common chronic pain syndromes come to the attention of the rheumatologist demanding for differentiation from fibromyalgia (FM), although they are often associated with it.	3.2336974634735216
They may mimick FM by (1) the occurance of wide spread pain, (2) the chronicity of complaints, (3) the preponderance of females in some of these, and (4) the lack of objective data to be derived from imaging techniques and laboratory tests.	3.7082327650974682
Pain is produced by the disturbance of normal function ("dysfunctional syndromes", MASI, ref.	3.310295943390535
Recognition requires examination of the locomotor system under biomechanical auspices both at rest and during movement in order to diagnose hyper- and hypomobility syndromes; treatment of these conditions is guided by principles to improve biomechanical function.	3.767286560620967
In addition, the skin needs to be examined to detect panniculosis (also called "cellulitis"), which may be mixed up with FM due to its preferential occurance in peri- or postmenopausal women.	3.452554799636941
It is concluded that the aforementioned differential diagnosis needs to be considered appropriately in coinciding FM and all studies dealing with FM.	3.08133722426254

Multiple sclerosis is a rare disease in childhood.	3.936411840647445
Abrupt vessel closure of the dilated vessel continues to represent a significant limitation of coronary angioplasty.	3.4026503596116235
Despite increasing operator experience and improved technology, abrupt vessel closure continues to represent the most important complication of balloon angioplasty.	3.7161812786123023
Intracoronary stent implantation and pharmaceutical blockade of the GP IIb/IIIa receptor serve as effective tools in the prevention of abrupt vessel closure without completely resolving this problem.	3.1490541814088115
About 50% of patients presenting with abrupt vessel closure exhibit additional complications including myocardial infarction, necessity of CABG or death occurring in up to 10% of acute occlusions.	3.44608469959129

Since the skin dose becomes the limiting factor while deciding the tumorcidal dose, the detailed analysis of dose distribution in the build-up region is necessary for high-energy photon beams.	3.186677890930173
In this study the beam characteriwstics affecting the build-up and skin dose for 6- and 18-MV photons are analyzed.	2.8171474014338087
Measurements were made with 6- and 18-MV photons using a PTW parallel-plate ionization chamber (B23344-036) and a RDM-1F electrometer.	2.9407683517801324
Build-up ionization measurements were made with the chamber fitted into a 25 x 25 x 25 cm polystyrene phantom with a fixed SSD of 100 cm.	3.044521852866045
The entrance and buildup dose measurements were made with a polycarbonate and a mesh type metallic shielding tray and a 45 ° wedge.	2.929964135642596
Exit dose measurements were carried out for the graphite patient supporting assembly table top, 1.0 cm thick piece of wood and the 1.0 cm thick patient supporting perspex base frame for head and neck treatments.	3.1688337870937944
It was observed that the dmax decreased slightly with field size as with other accelerators.	3.1309649608722188
For both photon energies the surface dose was observed to increase with increase in field size.	3.436075544625338
It was also noticed that the dose in the build-up region increases slightly when the polycarbonate secondary blocking tray is introduced with the increase in surface dose.	3.0621621251373594
The data show that the tray pertubation factor (TPF) at surface decreases steadily with tray-surface distance for both photon beams for all field sizes.	2.9058798601148776
It was noted that the TPF was more when the polycarbonate tray was introduced at shorter tray-surface distances for both energies.	2.8352847240542864
At tray-surface distances above 60 cm the TPF almost remained close to unity for 6-MV photons for all field sizes, whereas the continuous decrease in TPF could be noted for 18-MV photon beams even after the TPF rewached unity.	3.115301424666571
The increase in surface dose with field size for both photon energies is due to the electron scattering from the intervening materials.	3.266090613727249
The increase in dose enhancement percentage with graphite compared to perspex supporting assembly indicates that the electron backscatter is proportional to the atomic number of the medium.	2.744025750088891

These criteria include structural, functional, histological, and electrophysiological abnormalities, which were divided into major and minor criteria.	3.554075726975613

Global or segmental dilatation of the right ventricle in the sense of major criteria could be proven in 20 patients (83%) using angiography or electrocardiography.	3.9921685944660337
Four patients (16%) exhibited only minor criteria in the radionuclear angioscintigraphy or right ventricular angiography in the form of segmental kinetic disturbances of the right ventricular.	3.7217222493778843
In all patients, the typical fibrofatty replacement in the right ventricular myocardium could be histologically determined.	3.5425583423034355
