Because of hematogenous formation of metastases and bad prognosis in most cases we recommend that the surgical intervention be followed by the well tolerated systemic chemotherapy with Doxorubicin and Ifosfamid.	3.913419270748475
This study compares the results of the outpatient-based program of the Cochlear Implant Center Ruhr with inpatient-based rehabilitation, which is almost exclusively performed in Germany.	3.240797473952874
The Department of Otorhinolaryngology at the University of Essen in Germany provided 52 patients with either 22- or 24-channel Nucleus cochlear implants from March 1996 to July 1999.	3.2218445138345544
Almost all patients (n=49) were rehabilitated on an outpatient basis, which is the standard in many cochlear implant centers outside Germany.	4.030997154138292
Syringe drivers are used in anaesthetics, intensive care and emergency medicine to deliver small volumes of highly potent drugs with continuous, constant and reproducible flow.	3.2523540837602325
For early recognition of interruptions of the drug delivery caused by occlusion of the infusion system, an alarm is triggered as soon as the system pressure exceeds a certain limit.	3.4498899701636665
The sensitivity of this alarm depends on the flow rate, type-specific cut-off pressure and the elastic parameters of the infusion system.	3.8191811070157047
The sudden release of pressure built up in the system after occlusion occurred can cause delivery of an uncontrolled drug bolus and hence an additional hazard.	3.2119418105457775
Methods: Six syringe drivers that are widely used in clinical practice were tested for alarm delay and bolus delivery in the event of an occlusion in the system.	3.5813787428974715
First, the alarm pressures at flow rates of 10, 50 and 100 ml/h were measured.	3.147965932691078
Then the alarm delay time and bolus volumes post-occlusion were assessed, using a basic infusion system (syringe+single infusion set).	3.152012295832948
Finally, several alterations to the system like extension, tap battery with germ filters or branching were made and their impact on alarm delay and bolus volume measured.	2.769347606253201
Results: Because of the great differences in alarm pressures between the devices tested, there were marked differences in the alarm delay at same flow rates.	3.9926837334264036
Predictably, there was an indirect proportional link between alarm delay and flow rate.	4.031554503261832
Using the basic infusion system, alarm delays between 23 s and 143 min were measured.	2.941774372634344
In two of the tested syringe drivers, a pressure-release mechanism is activated with the pressure alarm, which prevented bolus application.	3.1541822513732694
In the other devices, release of the pressure in the occluded system caused boli of 0.5-7 ml.	3.3401943029767813
Variations in the actual syringe volume and insertion of a second connection tube had no impact on alarm delay and bolus volume.	3.0599921147621454
Tap batteries, parallel running syringe drivers or trapped air in the system, however, caused marked increase in both alarm delay (107%) and bolus volume (+147%).	3.3016027924723597
Discussion: Unidentified occlusions of the system cause grave malfunctioning of syringe drivers.	3.3797558530558165
While applying highly potent drugs, the discontinuation of drug delivery with subsequent bolus application can cause vital danger to the patient.	3.0435807270188606
As a result of the significant time delays in the pressure alarms, the devices tested do not provide sufficient protection against unrecognized system occlusion.	2.9422466595035637
Syringe drivers with adjustable alarm pressure can be set close to the actual infusion pressure.	3.3025360894783247
A further important point is that one should aim at a reduction in the elastic properties of the infusion set because of the great impact on alarm delay and bolus volume.	3.5474513504094345
However, minimally invasive methods such as stabilization by external fixation and percutaneous K-wire pinning are being increasingly used.	3.3330142745250173
A justified indication for the use of K-wire pinning is that it provides an opportunity to achieve good and very good short- and long-term anatomic and functional results.	3.9840578307150007
Short-term supplementary immobilization with a minimized plaster cast or protective external fixation is generally considered to be useful.	3.6702743644480966
Reports on plaster-free functional treatment after K-wire pinning have been published.	3.1550964159341537
The indications therefore need to be further specified.	3.682458950429047
Follow-up studies and an analysis of our patients show a strong increase in K-wire stabilization and good-to-very good results in 75% of the cases.	4.3159286641179255

Classical stable plate osteosynthesis with its anatomical repositioning, absolute stability between fragments and medial support should only be applied to joint fractures and spongy bone.	3.1533259333754198
In cortical bone, the anatomical reposition connected with the plate promotes bone necrosis along the fracture and prevents callus formation.	3.389385983602726
Direct cortical synthesis, a method also known as "primary bone healing", serves the bone's revascularisation and is not necessarily aimed at healing.	3.3639176298010662
Thus, this may also be termed "necrosis healing".	3.375478515316818
Along the shaft of long bones, elastic plate osteosynthesis, a biological method, is safer than and superior to the rigid technique.	3.3422508244199194
This even applies to short oblique and transverse fractures insofar as nailing does not appear feasible.	2.876142619847332
Elasticity is achieved by leaving a flexible stretch of at least 2 - 4 holes, i.e.	3.6432516884427715
as long as possible, without screws over the fracture and by employing a titanium plate.	3.975886995036941
The fitting of third fragments is deliberately left out.	2.993407996202593
The same applies to all kinds of compression with lag screws, tension devices or DC-gliding holes - and this with the intention of allowing micromovements in the fracture's fissure.	2.790972406603521
Periost and muscle are not removed and the fracture is not examined.	3.6627324689475027
Histomorphological investigation dates the first woven- bone bridges between the fragments to 3 weeks subsequent to the accident.	3.1880265924372915
In Göttingen University trauma centre, 87 fractures have been attended to over 2 years using this technique.	3.1025648442513245
Despite considerable soft-tissue damage, no delayed bone healing, pseudoarthrosis or bone infection has been observed.	3.3886049072840816
The risks of elastic plate osteosynthesis lie in unbiological and exaggerated reposition methods, too short a flexible stretch, and insufficient anchorage of the screws.	2.855420737157314

In 26 patients with abscesses in the maxillofacial area, the electrolyte concentrations, pH and osmotic and hydrostatic pressures of the pus fluid were measured and calculated.	2.9818042757464274
The main cations identified were sodium (134  +/-  38 mmol/l) and potassium  (37  +/-  16 mmol/l) and as anions chloride (183  +/-  46 mmol/l) and bicarbonate (10  +/-  4 mmol/l).	3.01106731025693
The pH value of the pus liquid was 6.164  +/-  0.233.	3.194856163199543
The calculated mean osmotic pressure of the pus liquid was 7910  +/-  1455 mm Hg, whereas the measured physical pressure inside the abscess was 49  +/-  13 mm Hg.	3.109687815388171
Both pressure types show time-dependent pressure curves.	3.6408882969730545
With time, the real pressure inside the abscess cavity increases, whereas the osmotic pressure decreases.	3.456293213078312
There was no relationship between the two pressure types and the different species of microorganisms responsible for the inflammation.	3.946863871878577
The results of the study reveal that abscesses can be regarded as osmotically active systems, and the mechanism by which the abscess is formed might be as follows.	3.652819445557286

This topical application avoids systemic side effects such as skin sensitization.	3.450482332798364

Increases in threshold are immediately followed by an adaption of the pulse amplitude.	3.3151006948222608

Medial tilting of the talus with vertical position provokes flattening of the medial arch and abduction of the forefoot.	3.558516131002398

Repair of deformities in the hindfoot therefore also influences the forefoot.	3.205370885613142
A large number of various osteotomies have been proposed at both bones.	3.303713043887253
The most popular ones are Dwyer's osteotomy at the corpus of the calcis and its modification described by Mitchell at the same location for correction of the cavus foot and the residual clubfoot, and the lengthening osteotomy at the neck of the calcaneum according to Evans.	3.097100470103745
Indication and operative technique of these three procedures are described in detail.	4.057846618574691
The closing wedge osteotomy according to Dwyer is indicated in cases of cavus feet.	3.563820421065062
In clubfeet the os calcis is usually too short and the medial opening wedge osteotomy provokes skin problems.	3.1436990334654125
In these cases an osteotomy according to Mitchell with lateral displacement of the tuber calcanei is more suitable.	2.82555618846354
In flat- and skewfeet a lengthening osteotomy at the neck of the calcaneum according to Evans can be indicated, especially when the load of the foot is bigger medially under the talus rather than at the lateral margin of the foot.	3.0881351772973304
If these procedures are carried out carefully, they have low complications rates.	3.0856588518239065

Definition of the problem: In parallel with public and philosophical discussions, there is an ongoing debate about euthanasia in theological ethics.	2.828575023034051
In this situation it is helpful to provide a systematic overview of the different arguments and judgements.	3.376928527493486
Arguments: A short introduction is followed by a first part dealing with the definition of terms.	3.5683736495673966
The second and major part concerning normative arguments is subdivided into three steps: the level of principles, the more concrete level of actions and finally the level of social consequences.	3.3158820451655235
The third part presents some reflections following the eudaimonistic ethical tradition (the ethics of a good life and death) focusing on the central question: how to find meaning in life when faced with suffering.	3.0035796688296252

The human cartilage and bone is characterized by a remodeling during the life, well balanced by neosynthesis and degradation of matrix components.	3.219916871718353
In different joint diseases, it becomes imbalanced and the destruction of the cartilage supersedes the repair.	3.4118657784110957
In tissue processes in disease and in normal turnover of the matrix, these molecules are fragmented and released into surrounding fluids, in the synovial fluid, and then in the blood and the urin, where they can be detected.	3.865476455475099
The quantitative measurement in the synovial fluid is more specific than in the other body fluids.	3.738036656412635

Axillary block is a common anaesthetic technique for operations on the hand and forearm.	4.1216289499295335
In our hospital, with many trainees in anaesthesia, only 250 - 300 axillary blocks per year are performed by about 30 colleagues.	3.0978093518660095
This implies a small number of blocks for each anaesthetist.	3.663205096679681
The present study was designed to assess whether it is possible to teach this technique and use it with an adequate degree of success under these conditions.	3.1812513309926542
We used a nerve stimulator and studied whether the success of the block under these conditions is independent of anaesthetist's experience in this technique.	2.8472801257063387
Furthermore, we examined other factors involved in the success of the block.	3.637162296131418
The study included 112 patients subjected to elective surgery of the upper extremity; all received an axillary block.	3.2157454789753586
We used a nerve stimulator and injected mepivacaine 1% without adrenaline.	2.407571888579779
The following parameters were recorded: the number of blocks to date performed by the anaesthetist; the minimal current required for nerve stimulation; the dose of local anaesthetic; the time between the end of injection and the beginning of surgery; the duration of surgery; and the quality of sensory and motor blockade after 10, 20, and 30 min.	4.2966137152372115
Sensory blockade was assessed by the pinprick method (no blockade, analgesia, anaesthesia); motor blockade was judged by comparing the muscle strength of both arms (no blockade, paresis, paralysis).	3.065620238202424
Data were analyzed using the Mann-Whitney test, with P<0.05 considered statistically significant.	3.0986709854187
Of the 112 blocks, 95 (85%) were successful; 17 (15%) failed and the patients required general anaesthesia.	3.435662513602908
Eight of the successful blocks showed a decrease in analgesic quality after >=70 min and required additional analgesics or general anaesthesia.	3.3295110657172557
We found no correlation between the experience of the anaesthetist and the success of the block.	3.4257746713716646
The minimal required current for nerve stimulation in the success group was 0.4 mA and differed significantly from the value of 0.6 mA in the failure group (Table 3).	3.091085324655194
Complete sensory blockade was more frequently achieved for the median, ulnar, and radial nerves than for the musculocutaneous and cutaneous brachii medialis (Fig.	2.9392894269080685
The frequency of complete sensory blockade (anaesthesia) had increased by 21.9% between the 20th and 30th min.	2.951812395960971
Complete motor blockade was less often achieved than sensory blockade (Fig.	3.152480193231918
Using the method of electrostimulation, the axillary block is an appropriate anaesthetic technique that can be applied in a hospital where each anaesthetist only occasionally performs it.	4.13367432077699
Prior to injection of the local anaesthetic, the current for nerve stimulation should be reduced to <0.5 mA.	3.7469914163801294
The time between the end of injection and the beginning of surgery should be no less than 30 min because complete sensory blockade can more often be achieved.	3.1306324070143456
The dose of mepivacaine should be no less than 6 mg/kg body weight.	3.34974253325891
Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) was discovered 10 years ago as a growth factor that can regulate angiogenesis and in addition the permeability of blood vessels.	3.5022697994182583
Numerous studies have revealed that it is essential for normal embryonic development and that it plays a major role in physiological and pathological events of angiogenesis in adults.	3.5033844415236524
It is unique in that its expression is regulated directly by hypoxia.	3.067584325785867
Five VEGF forms of 121 to 206 amino-acids are produced from a single gene by alternative splicing.	3.017002800573896
Cells expressing VEGF usually express several forms simultaneously.	3.0776887722966775
VEGF121 does not contain exons 6 and 7 of the gene and consequently lacks a heparin binding ability.	3.563386197023945
However, this form is fully  active as an inducer of angiogenesis, and as a blood vessel permeabilizing agent.	3.1468455925906427
Exon 6 and 7 contain 2 independent heparin binding domains.	3.4400951142633156
The VEGF form containing exon 7 (VEGF165) and the vascular endothelial growth factor form containing exon 6 (VEGF145) display similar biological potencies raising the question of why so many VEGF forms are required.	3.169929824084726
It was found that VEGF121 diffuses better because it does not bind to heparan-sulfate proteoglycans.	2.7281793576561397
In contrast, VEGF145 binds to extracellular matrix ad is released from it slowly.	2.601730105280711
When the receptor binding properties of VEGF121 and VEGF165 were compared it was found that VEGF165 binds to a class of VEGF receptors that is not recognized by VEGF121.	2.9967576990853497
We have recently found evidence indicating the neuropilins form complexes with another VEGF receptor, VEGFR-1.	2.825504431996038
However, the biological function of this complex remains to be elucidated.	3.355493690139086

The typical clinical features of myasthenia gravis are weakness and excessive fatiguability of striated muscles that increases during the course of the day or after strenous exercise.	3.285634188175856
Ocular muscle involvement with ptosis (in 50%) and diplopia (in 25%) are the most common initial signs.	3.6441582573672022
The disease can progress to bulbar muscles and to all other striated muscles (generalized myasthenia).	2.9935215550582543
The muscle fatiguability and a fluctuating course can mislead to a diagnosis of neurasthenia.	3.255246663524738
Since the treatment of myasthenia gravis is directed at the pathogenetic mechanisms of the disease an early diagnosis is of great significance for the course of the disease.	4.534222175914774
Also, a false positive diagnosis of myasthenia has to be avoided because of the potentially hazardous side effects of the therapy.	4.751908210742886
The mainstay of the diagnosis is the history and a subtle clinical examination with tests of excessive muscle fatiguability.	3.774008823033254
The injection of edrophonium (Tensilon), the electrodiagnostic testing after repitive stimulation (decrement test) and the testing for serum antibodies against acetylcholin receptors have to be performed to secure the diagnosis of myasthenia.	4.032335994941446
Antibodies are present in 50% of ocular myasthenia and in 80-90% of the generalized form.	3.589819259348055
The Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, other neuromuscular diseases, mitochondrial diseases, diseases of the cranial nerves, botulism and the rare congenital myasthenic syndromes have to be considered as differential diagnosis.	3.3121326582513917

The potention for regeneration of cartilage tissue is minimal and leads to mechanically inferior fibrous tissue.	3.048372198826417

According to diameter of the blood vessels involved in the inflammatory process, the clinical presentation and the histological appearance, different vasculitic syndromes may be distinguished.	4.282814251221796
Primary vasculitides are of unknown origin while secondary vasculitides may be caused by drugs, malignancy or infection.	3.1695977029003006

After successful treatment of the infection, the vasculitis usually subsides.	3.4159237520603187

The draining sinus is an unpleasant complication of acne conglobata, acne fulminans, acne inversa, rosacea conglobata and rosacea fulminans (pyoderma faciale).	2.4634095124972317
It is most common on the face, especially in the nasolabial folds, and on the neck below the mandibular line.	3.6864375202242607

The lesion persists with no tendency to spontaneous regression.	3.15700882477792

Intralesional corticosteroid injection, cryosurgery and isotretinoin are not always very effective.	3.3118818544109527
Sometimes complete excision of the lesion is necessary.	4.4128895576598515
The draining sinus is a special form of scar analogous to the pilonidal cyst.	2.7666358584249218

Local anaesthetics are used by 85% of these anaesthesiologists, followed by morphine (72%), clonidine (48%), buprenorphine (34%), baclofen (20%), fentanyl (13%) and sufentanil (10%).	3.289472878978819
In the 137 answering pain clinics 79.821 epidural and intrathecal analgetic treatments are performed per year.	2.8404433646511533

Signs of IACD can be missed on the standard ECG, and signal averaged (SA) P wave analysis has proved valuable for the evaluation of electrophysiological (EPS) properties of atrial myocardium.	3.179214595378729
Unfavourable EPS effects of RAA pacing are known to electrophysiologists, but this aspect is rarely considered in normal practice, and RAA based pacing modes remain standard even for pts.	3.3590876947907304

with BiA pacing system (implanted due to atrial arrhythmias and IACD).	3.1305428518624594

BiA pacing normalises all atrial activation times.	3.318911223581583

indicates beneficial effects of BiA pacing (in pts.	3.5825000243706335
with IACD) in comparison to sinus rhythm and RAA pacing.	3.896662669203429

Chronic lymphoplasmacellular osteomyelitis may occur in children, adolescents and adults, but has not been found in newborns or babies either in our series or in the literature.	3.930097241810066
Symptoms suggesting an acute disease like fever are uncommon, but a primary chronic course with symptomatic and asymptomatic periods is typical.	3.1427003278806573
Pain and swelling are the main symptoms; painless masses are rare.	3.5614468314681242
In children and adolescents the clavicle and metaphyseal regions of long bones are typical sites of chronic abacterial osteomyelitis.	3.2977001136685895
In adults the clavicles or the first two ribs are mainly affected with synovitis of the adjacent joints, but the long bones are rarely involved.	3.5359887784155473
Laboratory findings are non-specific but important for the differential diagnosis.	3.434458856440359
The sedimentation rate and c-reactive protein might be elevated.	3.381636547746655
The X-ray examination shows osteolytic, sclerotic or mixed bony changes and, in case of a diaphyseal involvement, onionskinlike periosteal bone formation may be present, suggesting a malignant process.	3.393907490517439
In late stages sclerotic bone formations may be seen as a rest.	3.103675928623004
Uni- or multifocal lesions can be detected by bonescan, as can asymptomatic lesions.	3.6249751471019613
Magnetic resonance imaging shows gross signal intensity differences both in the bone and perifocal soft tissue and involvement of the synovium with gadolinium DPTA enhancement in T1-weighted images.	3.1675511330005204
In early stages of the disease granulocytes, microabscesses and new bone formations might suggest bacterial osteomyelitis that cannot be differentiated by histology.	3.2222920567271633
In intermediate phases lymphocytic and plasmacellular infiltrates are found, whereas in late phases sclerotic bone formations and fibrosis of the bone marrow are seen histologically.	3.432791418709053
In chronic lymphoplasmacellular osteomyelitis, all clinical, radiological and histological findings, as well as negative bacteriological cultures, are mandatory and will allow a definitive diagnosis to be made.	3.334975042621709
The disease may be uni- or multifocal, and new bone lesions may occur over time, as well as skin manifestations, which can be found years before or after bone involvement.	4.225010306552802
The association with dermatological diseases and/or synovitis led to the acronym SAPHO syndrome (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteomyelitis).	3.30771624033432
For the treatment non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are effective for pain relief, reduction of swelling and dysfunction.	3.3903315164764747
Antibiotics have been used in several series and are not effective.	4.169495009981214
Major surgery is not recommended even for recurrences, and the prognosis for growth and function is excellent in the long term despite recurrences over several years.	4.37092346560486

Sevoflurane, like all currently used volatile anaesthetics, is degraded by carbon dioxide absorbents.	3.0034744964763993
The most significant degradant is a haloalkene known trivially as "compound A".	2.9166268070983397
Compound A is nephrotoxic in rats and, at higher doses, in nonhuman primates, causing proximal tubular necrosis.	3.2680408932374143
There has been much interest in the potential for compound A toxicity in humans.	3.064824427010691
Inhaled compound A concentrations are greatest at low flow rates, high sevoflurane concentrations, warmer absorbent, barium hydroxide vs soda lime, and drier absorbent.	2.874864579589289
Typical inspired compound A concentrations during low-flow and closed-circuit sevoflurane anaesthesia in humans are 8-24 and 20-32 ppm with soda lime and barium hydroxide lime, respectively.	3.1072717345867558
Renal effects of compound A production during sevoflurane anesthesia have been examined in surgical patients and volunteers, using standard (creatinine clearance, serum BUN and creatinine) and experimental (urine excretion of protein, glucose, NAG, GST, AAP) markers of renal function.	2.730926257976935
Investigations to date in surgical patients show similar renal effects of low-flow sevoflurane, low-flow isoflurane or high-flow sevoflurane.	4.285331603116483
There have been no case reports of compound A-associated renal injury in humans.	3.0851298162141
In volunteers, one study found changes in experimental but not conventional renal markers, while other investigations show no significant changes in either standard or experimental markers.	3.0589356127288037
The mechanism of compound A nephrotoxicity in rats appears to involve metabolism to glutathione and cysteine conjugates, and their subsequent renal uptake and metabolism by pathways that are different in rats and humans.	2.9283057590236607

The common clinical feature of group 1 was a thorax trauma in combination with pneumonia (85 % survivors).	3.322142739622876
Patients with decreased IL-12 levels revealed also a thorax trauma and pneumonia but all patients succumbed.	2.9071109261926207

Conclusions: After major injuries there is no overall suppression of IL-12 formation.	3.855685579586114

This article reviews the pathogenesis and clinical and imaging findings in shoulder impingement syndrome.	2.920554410304543
Shoulder impingement is caused by compression of the supraspinatus tendon underneath the coracoacromial arch, mainly in forward flexion of the arm.	3.4184083918168633
Stage I relates to edema and hemorrhage of the supraspinatus tendon.	3.201404593031689
Stage II is characterized by bursal inflammation and fibrosis, as well as tendinopathy.	4.653835248794628
In stage III there is a tear of the rotator cuff.	3.8896921813266725
Moreover, calcifying tendinitis, fractures and pain originating from the cervical spine may mimic shoulder impingement syndrome.	2.914566114731765
Imaging is important for the exact diagnosis.	4.184816916476414
Standard radiographs are the basis of imaging in shoulder impingement syndrome.	3.642987837781174
They may demonstrate subchondral sclerosis of the major tuberosity, subacromial spurs, and form anomalies of the acromion.	3.2021694913159373
They are also important in the differential diagnosis of shoulder impingement syndrome and demonstrate calcifying tendinitis, fractures and neoplasm.	3.3046161305888075
Ultrasonography has found acceptance as a screening tool and even as a final diagnostic method by many authors.	3.651602900170064
However, there is a high interobserver variability in the demonstration of rotator cuff tears.	3.3277397695201243
Its usefulness has therefore been questioned.	3.4876850501964833
MR imaging is probably the method of choice in the evaluation of the rotator cuff and surrounding structures.	3.860112408490697

Possible mechanisms are reviewed based on the work by others and ourselves on somatosensory reorganization in humans.	3.541873024635968

On the other side, sensorimotor training can increase the representational cortical zone of a limb.	2.9432195504696432
Plastic changes can be temporary or persistent.	3.4065613135069035

Trauma scores in emergency medicine quantitatively characterise the severity of trauma victims' injuries and physiologic derangements.	3.766722908781931
They are used to detect and assess patients and have applications in guiding patient care and early therapeutic decisions.	3.5197665284513557
In the pre-clinical setting, an effective trauma index meets the following criteria: - It is highly reliable with regard to identifying high- and low-risk patients.	3.402073724884063
- It has high face-validity.	2.8533873486371757
- It has high inter- and intra-rater reliability.	3.008501100709239
- It is easy to use and allows rapid, accurate measurements.	3.3944867377858925
The most widely accepted injury severity index is probably the Injury Severity Score (ISS).	3.1472758707463147
It is calculated as the sum of the squares of the three most severely injured body regions, and was originally developed as a means to standardise the description of injuries sustained in motor vehicle accidents.	3.1179583869668437
The Trauma Score (TS) represents the gold standard of physiologic scoring of injury severity.	3.312090414838826
It summarises the numerical assessments of the central nervous and cardiopulmonary system functions.	3.3708831966340895
The recently developed Mainz Emergency Evaluation Score (MEES) is based upon numerical specification of the vital signs, including a pain scale, and has been designed as a dynamic score.	3.2786666052998474
Nevertheless, limitations of the established trauma score systems have been described.	3.5229113572247757
Mortality and patient outcome do not strictly correlate with injury severity scoring.	3.122330234865927
In addition, intubated or paralysed patients were excluded from outcome studies since the scoring systems lacked options for evaluation of pathophysiological conditions after therapeutic interventions.	2.8427632632286413
Thus, therapeutic efficacy could hardly be assessed, and subsequent scoring during time periods was impossible.	3.0200549152298164
The accurate definition of comprehensive evaluation of a trauma victim is challenging, for example, "pain" as chosen in the MEES must be regarded as a highly desirable piece of information although its rating may prove difficult, especially when classifying unconscious patients.	3.141026296315739
Further criticisms of the above-mentioned trauma indices could include omission of the trauma victim's age, gender, pre-injury health status, or the influence of alcohol or additional medication.	3.691972915175241
Moreover, questioning the interrater reliability of injury severity scoring, a recent study revealed bias in assigning values to trauma patients: trained raters classified injury severity with significantly higher indices than less experienced researchers.	2.752742683286593
If trauma indices in pre-hospital emergency medicine were relied upon as the only means of evaluating a trauma patient and guiding therapeutic approaches, significant numbers of trauma victims requiring major interventions would be missed.	3.283717778391298
Resuscitative treatment regimens must not be based solely upon indices, since, e.g., in states of shock injury scores do not correlate with fluid resuscitative requirements.	3.184801778389224
Furthermore, a qualitative assignment of single vital-function parameters as crucial indices for a patient's condition never reflects the broad range of a patient's profile.	2.971435513342951
Many multiple-trauma patients do benefit from controlled ventilation in clinical experience even though pulse oximetry values are within the physiological range, and the administration of analgesics or even pre-hospital anaesthesia has often proved advantageous for trauma patients in the field.	3.9764214297243647
Providing the opportunity of subsequent patient evaluation and the efficacy of acute care, the MEES has been developed as a dynamic scoring system.	4.0851293873026995
This design is extremely desirable and must be regarded as an indispensible criterion for future scoring systems.	3.3416307076499825
In view of the peculiarities of field emergency medicine, pre-hospital indices do have limitations.	2.9862666177509265
The parameters "unknown patient", time pressure, unprecise measurements, lack of diagnostic facilities, incomplete evaluation, and limited statistical power cannot be eliminated.	3.030965545914521
Accurate prediction of outcome within early time-frames is therefore not possible.	3.0759617209888135

Thus additional areas of competence should be incorporated into the hairdresser's training qualifications.	3.0520922698872694
Besides manual, creative and psychological aptitudes, "trichological competence" relating to the recognition of most important hair disorders, recognition of personal limitations and cooperation with the medical specialist are required.	3.0794658897993825
To optimize the interaction between the physician, hairdressers and the media, more effective communication and public activities from the medical profession are desirable, with success depending on full identification of the set goals, qualification and adherance to the standards determined by the medical speciality.	3.1788945911765922

Adenocarcinoma was diagnosed in the same part of the lung as was SCLC before treatment in five cases and in contralateral location in two.	4.739284509567252
Two tumors showed heterogeneous differentiation with small-cell and adenocarcinomatous components, and five had only adenocarcinoma.	3.45673575427412
The interval between histological evidence of SCLC and adenocarcinoma was 3 months-5 years.	3.145930865666413
From the specific findings in the respective patients we can offer two possible explanations for changing differentiation in SCLC after chemotherapy: (a) a primarily heterogeneously differentiated tumor with selection of adenocarcinomatous component under chemotherapy, and (b) an independently developed adenocarcinoma after successful chemotherapy of SCLC, as patients with treated SCLC are known to have an increased risk of non-SCLC.	3.5444070581954152
However, therapy-induced alteration of differentiation seems much more unlikely.	3.159278757653797
These findings should be considered in diagnosis and therapy of SCLC to allow early and appropriate reaction to non-SCLC components.	3.7312646051347422

Typical clinical features include liver and kidney failure as well as central nervous system involvement.	4.199022045588961
There are three main forms of the disease: the acute form with manifestation in newborn infants and the subacute and the chronic form in children older than one year of age.	3.2348698800940214
Experimental data and clinical as well as postmortem experiences have indicated that subdural hematomas are less frequent in acceleration injuries in traffic accidents compared to falls or assaults.	3.562292400409454
The present report demonstrates that this does not hold true in the same way for bridging vein ruptures (one of the predominant causes for subdural bleedings).	3.360004044806699
Ruptures of these vessels without subdural bleeding (SDB) are only seldom mentioned in the literature.	2.9620919085634876
However, if no SDB is present, no one will look for these structures.	3.1698132642526518
In our institute a systematic analysis of the bridging veins in all cases of lethal blunt head injury is made: prior to the careful morphological preparation we investigate these vessels by radiographic imaging after filling with contrast medium.	3.3042756893026723
6 car passengers (age between 4 and 31 years) which suffered a lethal head injury were examined in the last year.	3.8035060582995306
2 victims had impressed fractures with cerebral compression injuries.	3.1757995985493435
In 1 case the base of the skull was broken and in 3 cases no skull fracture was present; no serious focal brain injury had occured in these 4 cases, but 3 victims had signs of diffuse brain injury.	3.46390385661685
In 5 cases a direct impact of the head against the interior of the car was obvious.	3.465420026539578
In 5 cases ruptures of serveral bridging veins could be demonstrated.	2.6808694885816355
In one case (survival for 3 days) a minor SDB (20 ml) was present and the ruptures had been closed by thrombosis; another victim died at the scene.	3.2171553208990242
The other 3 victims survived between 4 and 15 hours without developing SDB and without closing of the ruptures by thrombosis.	2.9415496955030664
This combination is surprising and shows that our knowledge concerning the relationship between bridging vein ruptures and SDB is restrictred.	3.322650524858404
The frequency of bridging vein lesions in severe head injuries is likely underestimated in the clinical as well as in the postmortem literature.	3.697737643480516
A rapid increase of intracranial pressure after the accident resulting in a collapse of the cerebral circulation is probably responsible for the absence of the SDB in the presented cases.	4.039797796284687
Implantable hearing aids can form the basis of new surgical techniques for dealing with hearing problems originating in the inner ear, provided they are fully implantable.	3.312754688018524
Accordingly, a comprehensive, interdisciplinary, combined project was initiated at the ENT clinic of the University of Tübingen which was to conclude with operations to improve hearing via fully implantable hearing aids.	3.157365440414583
A novel electromechanical transducer for implantable hearing aids based on the piezoelectric principle is described.	3.4752050698794124
Unlike the piezoelectric transducers reported so far, this transducer does not rely on the bimorphic principle but on a circle-shaped, heteromorphic combination system consisting of a piezoceramic disc and metal membrane.	2.7962036376588055
Transfer of mechanical oscillations to an ossicle in the middle ear is effected by a directly fixed coupling rod or via suitable coupling elements.	3.1353567309759414
The transducer is highly tuned with a resonance frequency at the upper end of the spectral transfer range (greater than 10 kHz).	3.2201989709984526
Below this resonance and down to low frequencies, the frequency response of elongation is smooth with amplitudes of around 20 nm.	3.142158679582763
At low and middle frequencies of up to 1 kHz, these vibration amplitudes correspond to sound-pressure levels of around 90 dB SPL.	3.1257103991072372
At higher frequencies of up to 10 kHz, the output level increases to about 130 dB SPL.	3.5194646490884747
Nonlinear distortions are also very small at the highest levels (less than 0.1%) throughout the whole transfer range.	3.325049782391791
Electric power consumption at maximum levels is in the range of a few microwatts and is therefore significantly lower than that of electromagnetic systems.	3.844566982351798
Particularly, this makes it possible to use the transducer in fully implantable hearing aids for rehabilitation of sensorineural hearing loss.	3.0798797000722384

and 5.4 mg/kg bodyweight/h i.v.	3.4706304369614007
for the following 47 h).	3.4897073297036894

Serum melatonin levels exhibit a circadian rhythm with low levels during the day, rise in the evening and maximum levels at night between 2 and 4 a.m.. The most common localization was the posterior third of the medial meniscus in ipsilateral lesions.	3.4051217987100038

A coincidence of meniscal injury with first- or second-grade cartilage damage was documented  in 35 patients (39.3%), whereas 54 patients (60.7%) had normal intra-articular cartilage.	3.346655260020079
Cartilage damage was most frequent in patients who had previously undergone partial meniscectomy.	4.250898292339926

Treatment of chronic cancer pain with strong opioids is indicated in about 60-70 % of patients.	3.7096842057037933

The aim of our investigation was to analyse the supply of opioid analgesics to outpatients with cancer pain in the region of Hannover, which has about 1.1 million inhabitants.	3.6264217333174806
In Germany special prescription forms, i. e. triplicate forms, have to be used for the prescription of strong opioids.	4.011674509594863
At the time when our investigation took place prescriptions for outpatients had to be renewed every 7 days.	3.0229445891142817
For two observation periods of 6 months lasting from January to June 1988 and from January to June 1991 all of the opioid prescription forms that had been issued by general practitioners for clients of the AOK Hannover (one of the major medical insurance companies) were evaluated.	3.4604443648162966
The reasons for prescribing opioids were analysed by recording the diagnosis.	3.285007370596967
The individual treatment period on an outpatient basis during these 6 months was determined, excluding, e. g. days of hospitalization.	3.5716053456610775
The majority of the practitioners consisted of general practitioners and specialists in internal medicine.	2.871941214556313
Although these two groups mainly function as family doctors who are responsible for the basic therapeutical needs of their patients, only 22.6-33.8 % of these doctors prescribed opioids to outpatients.	3.293608641146439
In two-thirds of the patients, cancer pain was the reason for prescribing the drug.	3.4612369939779275
The total number of patients with a prescription for cancer pain was 164 in 1988 and 196 in 1991.	3.632048140387505
Altogether 1002 prescription forms in 1988 and 1065 prescription forms in 1991 had been issued for these patients.	3.2371953046803283
Applied to the individual treatment period as an outpatient, only 36.0 % of the patients in 1988 and 32.1 % in 1991 received a regular prescription of strong opioids every 7 days.	3.7139595094550772
The mean time interval between separate prescriptions was 16.8  +/-  25.4 days in 1988 and 19.4  +/-  29.1 days in 1991.	2.7993863005926793
Accordingly, the majority of patients with chronic cancer pain had been supplied with opioids only occasionally.	3.6053423434912863
Our data indicate a significant undertreatment of outpatients suffering from cancer pain.	2.8106897380521554
Taking into account the estimated total number of patients suffering from cancer, only 14.5 % (1988) and 19.0 % (1991) of all outpatients in need of strong opioids were supplied sufficiently with those analgesics.	3.350149850272307
Comparing the results from the observation period in 1988 with the results from 1991 it becomes obvious that the situation has not changed.	3.910104326358281
There are different reasons for the insufficiency of opioid treatment: many physicians as well as their patients are still afraid of the side effects of strong opioids.	3.6758745090411358
Therefore, it is necessary to improve education concerning this issue.	2.9761325295190257
The legal restrictions on the use of narcotics and their complexity are another important reason for doctors not to prescribe strong opioids.	3.1683261453331446
In 1993 the regulations were simplified; nevertheless, this has not led to a profound change in the attitude of the prescribing practitioners.	3.4373198256278776
Thus, further changes in legislation seem to be necessary so that the requirements for the prescription of strong opioids do not differ from other drugs.	3.3399977580662887

Methods: During aorto-coronary bypass operation, human muscle fibers were excised (n=32) and skinned using Triton-X-100.	2.963908227515616

Different concentrations of IL-1 and IL-6 were applied (pIL-1/IL-6 1-2x10-5-10-11M).	3.2459115971279875
Force generation, calcium sensitivity, and velocity of force generation and relaxation were measured.	3.287350025756646
(Experiments were carried out at optimal length, bath temperature 23 °C, and isometric conditions.)	3.2475018482987035
Results: None of the skinned muscle preparations of the human myocardium showed under the given experimental setup a significant change in contractility and relaxation after exposure to IL-1 and IL-6.	3.046872847519582
Despite using nonphysiologic concentrations of IL-1 and IL-6 (pIL-1/IL-6 10-5M) no significant effect occurred.	3.0376762444415246
Furthermore no difference in calcium-sensitivity of the contractile proteins following addition of IL-1 and IL-6 could be observed.	3.583441447800795
Conclusions: Thus, there is no experimental evidence for direct modulation of the contractile apparatus by IL-1 or IL-6.	3.7523189257651075
Given these results it is possible to exclude some potentially negative inotropic cascades that are mediated on the level of the contractile apparatus as the molecular mechanism.	3.3764086563268223
These data show that therapies which support myocardial contractility during sepsis by stimulation of the contractile proteins do not seem to be very promising.	3.639217512590194
Indications for intercarpal and radiocarpal resectionarthroplasty and fusions are osteoarthritis, KIEHNBÖCK'S disease, rheumatoid arthritis and several posttraumatic disorders of the wrist joint.	2.9524295345980964
The resection of carpal bones leads to severe instability patterns of the wrist.	3.1279125178939893
In conclusion we recommend resection-arthroplasty just for treatment of the thumb carpo-metacarpal osteoarthritis.	3.4906559362835665

Therefore this implants should be confined to rheumatoid patients.	3.108544532321522

Increasing numbers of monitors at the anaesthesiologist's workplace, providing more than 20 different parameters of the patient's condition, have already made it impossible to record all the values in a handwritten form.	3.410389974542226
In recent years computerised data-acquisition systems have been introduced into clinical practice in order to produce more reliable records.	3.9166288752895717
But after a 7-year experience in the use of such a system in cardiac anaesthesia, we have recognised certain problems that remain to be solved before automated record-keeping will achieve wider acceptance.	3.7819441813845196
The first is the handling problem, which was discussed in a previous paper [11].	3.6442058393534644
The second major problem is the appearance of artifacts, caused mainly by mechanical manipulations during the operation.	3.518725832548211
In this paper, 300 courses of anaesthesia that were recorded on-line during different cardiac surgery procedures were examined and the incidence as well as the kind of artifacts occurring were evaluated.	3.4396816794438
Algorithms were developed for each haemodynamic parameter to suppress these artifacts automatically by a subsequent analysing process; the efficiency of that "artifact filter" was validated in 35 of the 300 cases.	3.2265831143168606
Based on more than 30,000 values for each parameter, the incidence of artifacts was 3%-7%.	3.9730576808652858
However, only 0.1%-0.5% of the artifacts could not be eliminated by the filter.	3.3484755068573664
The method described here provided acceptable graphic printouts of the most important haemodynamic parameters (Figs.	3.4371183394577316
1b and 2b) and would also be suitable to serve as an input filter for automatically running anaesthesia data-examination processes, which are currently being developed in our clinic.	3.8255570051262517

Delayed diagnoses were defined as the difference between the ISS at discharge and the ISS at completion of diagnostics in the emergency department; this criterion was met best by clinic A with an ISS difference of two patients compared to five in clinic B and four in clinic C.	3.5929148380974882

However, a cause-effect relationship has not been established to date.	3.497843260319987

Aim of the study and methods: In the present study the correlation between ischemia induced ventricular tachyarrhythmias and a dynamic behavior of ventricular late potentials was investigated.	3.7385834982985817

Before EPS (t1), at every stimulation interval and after induction of a ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation (VT/VF) the lactate concentration was measured in arterial blood and in the coronary sinus for calculation of the myocardial lactate extraction.	3.6024694719246884
Furthermore, before investigation, after induction of a VT/VF and after a 10 minute recovery phase an analysis of the signal averaged ECG was performed.	3.3012534623619465
Nine patients showed a so-called "lactate reversal", i.e., an increase of the lactate concentration in the coronary sinus over the concentration of the arterial blood as an expression of ischemia development, during inducibility of a VT/VF (group A).	3.835197962877342
The control group consisted of 7 patients without ischemia related VT/VF (group B).	3.0387588889102166
Results: In group A significant changes of the three late potential criteria were found between t1 and t2 (QRS:115.61 +/- 13.86 vs. 126.06 +/- 16.74, p=0.08; RMS: 25.81 +/- 22.26 vs. 13.11 +/- 10.72, p=0.01; LAS: 37.72 +/- 19.26 vs. 50.06 +/- 10.72, p=0.01).	2.716409509733708
In group B, no significant changes could be measured.	3.929909866180708
Furthermore, the prevalence of late potentials increased in group A from 66% (t1) to 89% (t2), whereas in group B no increase was detectable.	3.5903087147576165
Conclusions: These data suggest a dynamic behavior of ventricular late potentials in correlation with the inducibility of ventricular tycharrhythmias due to ischemic circumstances.	3.2075993709264434
Recent studies and reviews continue to report a high mortality associated with the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which involves a severe inflammatory reaction within the whole lung that is frequently associated with multiple-organ failure.	3.478748741902291
Important factors contributing to the poor results in severe ARDS are the aggressive procedures required to maintain sufficient arterial oxygenation, such as mechanical ventilation with high inspiratory pressures and high inspired oxygen concentrations (FiO2) which themselves contribute to the progression of the disease.	3.373823815942403
As no specific therapy that reduces or prevents the general inflammatory reaction is known, current therapy is limited to procedures that minimize peak inspiratory pressures and FiO2.	3.2580942705284093
Therefore, pressure- and volume-limited ventilation modes with positive end-expiratory pressure, controlled hypercapnia, differential lung ventilation when appropriate, positioning (particularly prone), and aggressive dehydration are used.	3.2346625082872893
Should these procedures fail to improve arterial gas exchange, the patients may be additionally treated by veno-venous extracorporeal gas exchange.	3.1701206369803967
To reduce the risk of severe haemorrhagic complications due to high levels of systemic heparinization, systems internally coated with covalently bound heparin, which allow a lower level of systemic anticoagulation, should be used.	3.4456834710909594
From April 1989 to August 1993, 89 patients were transferred to our intensive care unit for treatment of severe ARDS; 52 were treated by combining the described conventional methods without artificial gas exchange (survival rate 88%) and 37 additionally underwent artificial gas exchange (survival rate 57%).	3.093955051505672
The overall survival rate was 75%.	3.221109667606642
On the basis of these experiences, we conclude that this step-by-step approach may improve survival in patients with severe ARDS.	3.376878527867818

Past research on the phenomenon of enhanced pain sensitivity in fibromyalgia syndome (FS) revealed evidence for both a higher pain magnitude in response to nociceptive stimuli (hyperalgesia) and a general perceptual amplification of sensations (hypervigilance).	3.287023023519358
In order to distinguish between these two aspects of disturbed sensory processing in FS, cerebral evoked potentials after brief painful laser and auditory stimuli were measured in 10 FS patients.	3.056757262215014
Results were compared with those from age-matched painfree controls.	3.6312243891634295
Amplitudes of middle-latency (N1) and long-latency (P2) laser evoked potentials (LEPs) were significantly higher in FS than in controls.	3.3249915278209827
Furthermore, laser intensity at pain but not at sensation threshold was lower in FS than in controls.	2.7684797707361843
However, auditory evoked potentials (AEPs) did not differ between groups.	3.2030629946286773

Complex mechanisms have evolved in mammalian cells for regulating cellular lifespan.	3.090571376145677
Normal cells demonstrate a strictly limited growth potential and senescence after a defined number of cell divisions.	2.995911210376069
In contrast, tumor cells often exhibit an apparently unlimited proliferation potential and are termed immortalized.	2.9221045609945375
It has been proposed that the progressive shortening of the tips of the eukaryotic chromosomes - the telomeres - is an important component of senescence and is involved in the control of cell cycle.	3.821219902374902
The enzyme telomerase adds TTAGGG repeats onto mammalian telomeres, preventing their shortening.	2.850340908094214
Telomerase is normally inactive in most somatic cells, but detectable in tumor cells.	3.209277959653738
The activation of telomerase in malignant cancers seems to be an important step in tumorigenesis in order to gain the ability of indefinite proliferation and to become immortal.	3.644469299470968
This review describes the present knowledge of telomeres and telomerase and their role in cellular senescence and human aging.	3.087837520868937
It summarizes aspects of telomerase in cancer and its function as a diagnostic and prognostic tumor marker.	3.775927102460651

New developments such as organ transplantation and immunosuppression also generated totally new groups of patients with very distinct conditions for the operative procedure.	3.814678137788949

We live in an epoch that could be designated as the post-Gutenberg-era.	3.2449411181554377
Writing is no longer the dominant sign system.	3.9850825042155464
It is replaced by electronic signs.	3.0981879510276356

These electronic signs developed quickly a life of their own.	3.5249545616573257
A totally new class of objects came into being, the class of virtual objects.	3.019117459777126
These are electronically transformed, completed or wholly electronically produced objects.	2.7281082594478687

A change of the socio-cultural understanding is also a consequence of this process.	3.4877133382391756

The early complications of the technique are usually minor and late complications are rare.	3.769551403798357

Injections with botulinum toxin type A (BTX) are considered the first-line treatment for spasmodic torticollis (ST), blepharospasm (BL) and hemifacial spasm (HFS).	2.831216482615796
Because BTX brings only temporary and partial relief, patients frequently try other additional therapies to minimize their symptoms.	2.8725428372434942

Two hundred questionnaires were considered (112 TS, 54 BL, 34 HFS).	2.960801333836547
BTX was rated subjectively the best therapy in all three diagnostic groups (median: 2=good effect).	3.701189474981288
Despite Citalopram and physiotherapy (median: 3=average effect), all other therapies were rated with a median of >=4 (=minimal effect).	3.599326496780195

In conclusion, BTX is the most effective treatment for patients with ST, BL and HFS, as rated subjectively.	2.9946225154121917

The perioperative morbidity and mortality is mainly influenced by the type and duration of surgery as well as the patient's preoperative state of health.	4.308729607004559
Anesthesia per se, however, may also result in severe perioperative (patho)physiological changes, which may be both desired (e.g.	3.373142765995607
analgesia, vasodilation in vascular surgery) or detrimental (e.g.	3.083163226858176
hypothermia, ventilatory depression) and which may differ depending on the anesthetic technique used (e.g.	3.2151050795788336
general anesthesia vs. regional anesthesia).	3.5087404968292417
Yet, all anesthestic techniques have in common, that their effects are not limited to the duration of the surgical intervention, but may expand far into the postoperative period.	4.304724799333342
Therefore, many trials have been performed in the past aiming to compare the impact of different anesthetic techniques on the incidence of postoperative techniques, no significant advantage of one or the other technique has been identified up to now with respect to postoperative mortality or severe morbidity.	4.425650205404546
This finding may be due to at least three factors.	3.9989591213148814
1) Many side-effects related to anesthesia - due to close postoperative monitoring - are detected and treated early in the postoperative phase (e.g.	3.231744763812699
in the recovery room), thereby preventing serious complications.	3.2039750198750605
3) Besides the factor 'anesthesia', may other factors contribute to the anesthesia related morbidity and mortality (e.g.	3.3068304028240187
the factor 'anesthetist') which are hardly quantified.	3.3830510576381365
The fact that clear advantages for a single technique have not yet been demonstrated must not, however, result in anesthetic 'nihilism'.	3.4119188347877745

M. Linehan developed "dialectical behavioral therapy" specifically to treat chronically suicidal borderline patients.	2.8088629471757685
It rests on a biosocial model that assumes a disorder in the regulation of emotions and in tolerance of stress.	3.1952910623396136

There is a lack of cross-sectional studies as well as of any analysis of the long-term course of mental health care costs.	3.856874279135389
This study combines data from two cost-studies on patients with schizophrenia, conducted in the same catchment area at an interval of 15 years, to draw conclusions about the long-term course of these costs.	3.702148644540059
The direct costs of comprehensive community based mental health care had increased by 77.0% during 15 years, while the costs of a permanents stay in a long-term ward of a psychiatric hospital had increased by 78.5% in the same period.	3.563970673621198
This increase was 27 and 28.5 per cent higher than the general rise in cost of living in Germany during the interval between the two studies.	3.818185424210756
Thus, this rise of costs must be seen as a consequence of the great deficits and the resulting basic improvement of care for chronically mentally ill patients in Germany, which was demanded by an expert-commission of the government in the mid-seventies.	3.656612534504142

In this review article data of retrospective studies on the therapeutic effects of oxygen are summarized and possible indications for this therapy suggested.	3.484065532196244
Studies in infants with chronic lung disease (CLD) showed that (i) if SaO2 was kept >= 93 % via generous prescription of home oxygen, rates of sudden death were much lower than in studies where this was less generously prescribed, (ii) weight gain was significantly better with O2 therapy than without it, (iii) increasing SaO2 from 82 to 93 % by providing low-flow oxygen resulted in a 50 % reduction of pulmonary artery pressure, (iv) hypoxia could cause a significant increase in airway resistance, and (v) low-flow oxygen reduced the frequency of intermittent falls in SaO2 to < 85 % even in infants who had values of >= 90 % at rest.	3.2833700282202085
These data suggest that oxygen therapy should be considered in CLD infants if baseline SaO2 is < 93 %.	3.206698306234534
For older infants, particularly with CF, only few data are available.	3.617548685456854
In these patients oxygen may only be given if SaO2 is < 90 % unless there are clinical symptoms related to hypoxaemia, e. g. pulmonary hypertension.	3.124802983050131
Regarding the practical aspects of home oxygen therapy, provision of liquid oxygen via nasal cannulae appears to be the method of choice.	3.378314608029223
Side effects include the risk of CO2 retention, which occurs occasionally in children with CF or sleep-related upper airway obstruction, but has not been reported for infants with CLD.	3.8755571717668076
To identify this potential side effect and to determine the exact amount of oxygen required, performance of a sleep recording of SaO2 and CO2 with and without oxygen is suggested.	3.509730841516292
In infants with CLD, home monitoring of oxygenation should also be considered.	3.3357874905617995

The detection of cytokines may elucidate the pathophysiological mechanisms that produce early systemic complications in acute interstitial (i) or necrotizing (n) pancreatitis (AP).	2.941004867115655
The increase in the level of cytokines in the blood of patients with AP may correlate with the severity of the disease.	4.509080995535388
In a prospective clinical trial from October 1992 to August 1993, 23 patients with AP were recruited and blood samples taken for cytokine detection by commercially available Elisa kits and C-reactive protein (CRP) by laser nephelometry.	2.799563229682303
Six of 11 patients with nAP died either early (n = 1) or of late septic complications.	3.4055666399013087
The peak of cytokine and CRP level in the first 3 days of hospitalization was used for calculation.	3.8908444412878285
The IL-6 concentration in the blood reached up to 2600 pg/ml in the 1st few days, depending on the severity of AP, and dropped to almost zero in the next days, independently of the clinical course.	3.2600921858471246
The differentiation of i- versus nAP, using a cutoff line of 600 pg/ml, was correct in 20 patients [87 %, sensitivity (SE): 82 %, specificity (SP): 91 %, P < 0.001].	3.264809882632081
The blood levels of IL-8 reached a maximum of 1381 pg/ml in the 1st few days, depending on the severity of AP, and showed a correlation with the clinical course in the following days.	3.0939330479270497
The peak of IL-8 blood levels indicated correctly the severity of AP in 18 out of 23 patients using a cutoff level of 200 pg/ml (accuracy: 78 %, SE: 82 %, SP: 75 %, P < 0.01).	3.1393077322881755
The CRP levels increased up to a maximum of 535 mg/l and indicated the course of AP correctly in 18 out of 22 patients (SE and SP 82 %, P < 0.01).	3.3937302189748793
There was no correlation between cytokine blood levels and mortality.	2.7755459645680456
In the blood samples of five patients with i- or nAP, no TNF- was detectable.	3.3083425819526555
The blood levels of IL-6, and to a lesser extent of IL-8 and CRP, can predict the severity and early systemic complications of AP.	3.9347552702983157
The excessive rise in cytokines can be explained by the stimulation of immunological cells (macrophages, lymphocytes and endothelial cells) in the course of AP, inducing early systemic complications.	3.603153503952583

Pore sizes less than 2 nm were not found in relevant numbers.	3.769578822737341
The materials BioOss, old and new Algipore, and Interpore200 contain a large interconnecting mesopore system (diameter < 1 µm).	2.8454260829382707
For the materials Biobase, Endobone, Perioglas, Allotropat 50, and Biogran this cannot be assumed.	2.730204495455674
The materials Ceros80, Ceros82, and Cerasorb evaluated a specific surface area between those and might include only a small part of these interconnecting pores.	3.0876429147429683

A multifactorial etiology underlies the  majority of cases of Alzheimer's disease (AD).	3.182699999180817
Both ill-defined environmental and genetic factors contribute to the development of the disease.	3.5459601006832497
Allele 4 of ApoE is a genetic risk factor.	3.670274175386183
Its presence increases the risk of developing AD.	4.174620014656088
However, presence of e4 is neither necessary nor sufficient for the disease to arise.	3.3016870449568163
Apart from the common multifactorial forms of the disease, there are rare variants which are inherited as Mendelian traits.	3.5712302117142456
To date three genes are known that can be  mutated in these rare forms of AD.	3.452727691435237
Of these, mutations in the gene presenilin 1 on chromosome 14 are most frequent.	2.8961938724156107
In addition, mutations in the gene presenilin 2 on chromosome 1 and in the amyloid precursor protein gene (APP on chromosome 21) occur in autosomal dominant AD.	2.9369443506606756
This article reviews our present knowledge of the genetics of AD and discusses its relevance for patients with AD and their relatives.	3.7602453258060375

The mean Hannover Polytraumascore was 35.6 points, the mean Injury Severity Score 27.6 points.	3.106223199725368
Osteosnthesis was performed in 21 pelvic ring fractures (53%), eight procedures (50%) in type B fractures and 13 (56%) in type C fractures.	4.008704768641861
In type B injuries the anterior pelvic ring was stabilized with a tension band wiring in four cases, in two patients with an external fixator and with plate osteosynthesis in one case.	4.2060760430632875
In type C injuries the external fixator was applied as the only stabilizing procedure in six patients.	3.54525911891044
In four cases the anterior ring was fixed with tension band wiring or plates and the dorsal aspect of the pelvic ring with sacral bars.	3.349312696578208
Three patients had their additional acetabular fracture plated through a anterior approach.	2.7808712090859053

The patients were classified using the pelvic outcome score proposed by the German Society of Trauma Surgery.	3.367107340244357
53.4% of the type B fractures showed a good clinical outcome, 47.6% a poor outcome.	3.8416271816158134
80% of the type B and 23% of the type C fractures had a good radiological outcome.	3.810278606535278
20% of type B and 77% of type C injuries had a poor radiological outcome.	4.009872485934156

The mortality rate was 28%.	3.361199553182576

The management of complex pelvic trauma consists of fracture treatment and interdisciplinary treatment of the associated injury.	3.424426515439749

Dysfunction of serotonergic neurotransmission has been associated with two different psychopathological syndromes - impulsive aggressivity resulting form a lack of stimulation of the "behavior inhibition system" on the one hand and the manifestation of clinical depression and compulsive syndromes on the other.	3.1231553217392904
The examination of primate behavior provides a model which may reconciliate these seemingly contradictory hypotheses.	2.9381159791197042

Patients and methods: 41 children with a mean age of 9.6 (3.7-16) years with recurrent atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) refractory to medical treatment (n=38) and recurrent syncope (n=3) underwent electrophysiologic (EP) study.	2.9875469287787846
In all patients dual AV-nodal physiology could be demonstrated during EP study and typical form of AVNRT (mean heart rate 220/min) could be induced by programmed atrial stimulation.	3.3196877356263097
A steerable 7 F ablation catheter was placed at the inferoparaseptal region of the tricupid valve annulus close to the orifice of the coronary sinus with the intention to record a late fractionated local atrial electrogram during sinus rhythm.	3.3637226668976514
Starting at this point radiofrequency current (500 kHz) with a target temperature of 70 °C was delivered with the intention to ablate the slow pathway.	3.5476845692147996
If a slowly accelerated junctional rhythm (<120/min) occurred during energy discharge, programmed atrial stimulation was repeated.	3.2700804755083195
Otherwise radiofrequency current was delivered step by step up to a septal position next to the tricuspid valve annulus.	3.163191350367434
Slow pathway ablation was defined as lack of evidence of dual AV nodal pathways during repeated atrial stimulation.	3.2551037790145516
Slow pathway modulation was defined as maximal one atrial echoimpulse after ablation.	3.1447090984424793
Results: The number of energy applications ranged from 1-19 (median 6).	3.471631992344439
In 35/41 patients slow pathway ablation could be achieved; in six patients the slow pathway was modulated.	3.394613187705684
In none of the patients permanent high grade AV block was observed.	4.061042871338654
During follow-up (mean 4.1 years) two patients had a recurrent episode of AVNRT after slow pathway modulation.	3.4877698179715604
All other patients are still free of AVNRT without medical treatment.	3.1164561298569224
Conclusion: Selective radiofrequency current ablation/modulation of the slow pathway is a safe and curative treatment of AVNRT in young patients.	3.213528034114103
All operations were carried out by the first author in succession using the same operative technique.	3.812942710656955

After exclusion of surgical or biological causes hemodynamic effects of the anesthetic techniques were suspected as the reason for the significant difference in blood loss.	3.781946331286852

The measured values confirm the physicochemical stability of the mixture of bupivacaine hydrochloride 0.06% and fentanyl 0.0002% over a period of 32 days.	2.757205261428262
The infusion bag can be stored for 4 weeks at room temperature.	3.326331496728634
The programming of a cochlear implant speech processor used by young children is often difficult, especially when the stimulus level associated with maximum auditory loudness (MAL) needs to be determined.	3.189661614913451
Excessively high stimulation should be avoided as this can have a traumatic effect.	3.725157913213314
The aim of this study was to determine if a relationship exists between the intraoperatively determined electrical stapedius reflex threshold (ESRT) and the postoperatively determined MAL and hearing threshold for 27 patients, each having one of three implant types.	2.762740121428057
The question of whether the ESRT provides a practical technique to simplify, improve and accelerate speech processor programming was investigated.	2.6041312091052013
For the monopolar stimulation mode used for the Med-El and Clarion implant systems, the average MAL and threshold was expressed as a percentage of the average ESRT across all electrodes.	3.101620201707193
For the "common ground" stimulation mode used for the Nucleus implant system, a parabolic transformation was used to relate MAL and ESRT to one another.	3.1283464849178517
These transformations between MAL values calculated from the ESRT and the actual MAL values, determined psychoacoustically, diverged considerably from one another.	3.0049257245328893
Therefore, it was not possible to determine the MAL from the ESRT with certainty.	3.8601923235572415
The ESRT does, however, provide a means to estimate an approximate upper boundary for the MAL, apart from its use to control implant function.	3.4493827736444165
The determination of the exact MAL will still need to be determined using behavioural techniques.	3.6451136777235273

Spontaneous rupture und false aneurysms of the non-arteriosclerotic aorta are rare.	3.3766392598883783

In this biomechanical study the implanted Unreamed Humeral Nail (UHN) has been tested concerning bending and torsional stiffnesses.	3.104629804843364
In literature other intramedullary implants have been critisized for insufficient rotatory stability especially in transverse and short oblique fractures of the humeral shaft.	3.1078496742687416
This study examined, whether the implanted UHN, as well as the UHN implanted with interfragmentary compression through a specific compression device, is able to augment torsional stiffness significantly.	3.427631157945852
To evaluate bending and torsional stiffnesses, the UHN has been compared biomechanically to the Russell-Taylor humeral nail (RT) in paired mid-shaft osteotomized cadaveric humeri.	2.5601170482645297
Identic paired comparison has been performed with the UHN without and UHN with interfragmentary compression.	3.4415703577053125
In anterior-posterior, as well as medio-lateral direction stiffness under four-point-bending is significantly higher in stabilizing with the RT.	2.9659987581503855
Under torsional loading with moments of 4 Nm, 6 Nm and 8 Nm the UHN reached more than the double torsional stiffness.	2.622301892206734
The RT, which is only dynamically interlocked, owns a high initial "play" between bolts and nail itself.	3.315825090981834
Through additional interfragmentary compression stiffness of the UHN under four-point-bending in anterior-posterior, as well as medio-lateral direction augments significantly.	2.6786596902675335
Also under torsional loading with moments of 4 Nm, 6 Nm und 8 Nm torsional stiffness increases with interfragmentary compression significantly.	2.432286127437203
In comparison to other biomechanical studies of different autorship it is clear, that this statically interlocked intramedullary nailing of the humeral shaft is superior to non-statically interlocked types of nailing concerning their stabilizing potency in torsion and serves especially for fracture types, which are critically under rotation, as transverse or short oblique humeral shaft fractures.	3.176645587967887
While the different national health systems merge structurally, cost expansion in health care is a global challenge.	3.0506558538968043
Structural reforms have been developed during recent years in the USA which can be summarized as "managed care".	4.325772843115148
They are characterized by the evolution of an economically orientated system, in which units of medical therapy are generally handled like conventional economical goods.	3.7273229666476726
In managed-care models, patients are deliberately directed to the most economic forms of therapy.	3.7715981590251

The autonomy of medical decisions is clearly reduced to enforce an integrated and economically oriented steering of the health system.	3.0966009277055004
Leadership is no longer primarily confined to doctors or scientists.	3.667022993615079
It is progressively shifting to financing institutions, managing directors or insurance companies.	2.6839086772259977
Structural changes currently are expanding rapidly in the U. S. and have meanwhile led to marked regional reductions of medical costs.	2.651868945751232
Nevertheless, the US model is still far more expensive compared to the German system.	3.730708236322786

On the subject of natriuretic peptides there is a great deal of controversy, and intensive research efforts have been made studying their effects on electrolyte homeostasis.	3.6393599130326226
In the early 1980s, a peptide that caused diuresis, natriuresis, and had a relaxant effect on vascular smooth muscle was discovered independently by several groups.	2.88535323551297
This was the breakthrough for the identification of natriuretic peptides, followed by the characterisation of the amino-acid sequences of several species.	3.2963029427241746
Synthesis of the peptide, cloning of the encoding gene, identification and characterisation of specific receptors, as well as the development of antibodies and radioimmunoassays were rapidly accomplished.	3.5339671611394134
Research on the immunohistochemistry of cardiodilatin/atrial natriuretic peptide (CDD/ANP) and the regulation of CDD/ANP gene expression led to detection of the peptide in extra-atrial tissues.	3.39842681972704
Later on, two new peptides were discovered brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and C-type natriuretic peptide (CNP).	3.0810315586107797
These peptides share structural features with CDD/ANP with regard to their 17-amino-acid-exhibiting loop bridged by a disulfide bond.	3.0023353653430513
Another recently discovered peptide is urodilatin (URO), a renal-borne new member of A-type natriuretic peptide.	3.2764841715143276
URO was isolated from human urine and consists of the same sequence as CDD/ANP, containing the 17-amino-acid residue loop of the circulating hormone with 4 additional amino acids located at the NH2-terminus of the peptide.	3.1667486098946873
Regarding physiological actions, data strongly support a close association between URO and urinary sodium excretion.	2.995793869711311
The application of URO in animals revealed a stronger diuresis and natriuresis with a lower influence on arterial blood pressure compared to CDD/ANP-99-126.	2.9759050184838713
These results were encouraging for the use of URO in clinical trials as a tool to prevent acute renal failure (ARF) in patients following heart transplantation and for treatment of incipient ARF in patients following liver transplantation.	3.9208461189075017
Summarising the results of these two studies, URO represents a new approach for not only prevention, but also for treatment of ARF following organ transplantation.	4.479482711691494
This opens up new possibilities for the treatment of ARF of other origins in intensive care medicine.	3.3428249259038827

Introduction: Bile duct complications after laparoscopic cholecystectomy occur twice to three times more frequently than after an open procedure.	3.239734293550731
Four different types of lesions may be differentiated by the Siewert classification: postoperative bile fistulas (type I), late strictures (type II), tangential injuries of the bile duct (type III) and defect lesions (type IV).	3.5676363771351065
The diagnostic and therapeutic management is demonstrated in relation to our own experience and the literature.	4.976663776120737
Methods: Eleven patients (median age 43.8  +/-  17.2) with bile duct complications after laparoscopic cholecystectomy were operatively treated between November 1993 and December 1998.	2.966034302093586
Nine patients (four type-II lesions, five type-IV lesions) were referred from another hospital; 2 defect lesions out of 410 laparoscopic cholecystectomies (0.5 %) were documented in our own patient group.	3.155747935376467
Results: Four patients with late strictures were operatively treated with a hepaticocholedochostomy (n = 2) or hepaticojejunostomy (n = 2) after 14.3  +/-  8.4 months and were discharged from hospital after 10.6  +/-  3.8 days.	3.319145095396961
In both cases with type-IV lesion and a short defect, an end-to-end anastomosis was successful (hospital stay 11.6  +/-  1.0 days).	3.2339509466111025
However, a retrocolic Roux-Y end-to-side hepaticojejunostomy was perfomed in all cases with a larger defect (n = 5; hospital stay 14.8  +/-  2.0 days).	3.2970331178259378
The two defect lesions in our own group were detected by intraoperative cholangiography and immediately treated after conversion either with hepaticocholedocho-stomy or hepaticojejunostomy (hospital stay 11.2  +/-  0.6 days).	3.1081775759434844
Conclusions: The incidence of bile duct complications after laparoscopic cholecystectomy might be kept down by anatomic preparation, selective intraoperative cholangiography and early consideration of conversion to open procedure.	3.011134219778615
The clinical course after biliary tract injury can be positively influenced only by a standard diagnostic and operative procedure and by an early transfer to a specialized center.	3.1986333394342403

The mortality of perioperative myocardial infarction is still high and according to recently published data amounts to 17 to 42%.	2.9556885140523366
In the seventies introduction of thrombolytic therapy has led to a dramatic reduction in mortality of non-perioperative myocardial infarction.	3.7955898484037287
However, in the perioperative situation thrombolytic therapy remains to be problematic in most cases because of expected severe bleeding complications.	3.41192740443315
In the last 4-6 years acute-PTCA has been established in the therapy of acute myocardial infarction.	3.5109511835685
Up to date no data are available concerning the effect of acute-PTCA on mortality of perioperative myocardial infarction.	3.516057750637
Nevertheless it can be assumed, that acute-PTCA will lead to a considerable reduction in mortality of perioperative myocardial infarction.	3.820569712106583
Therefore, in patients with significant perioperative myocardial infarction immediate coronary angiography and, if indicated, acute-PTCA should be performed.	4.223673602668258
In principle, thrombolytic therapy is considered to be contraindicated in the intra- or postoperative situation.	3.55527323876719
However, if coronary angiography and PTCA are not possible, thrombolysis might be taken into consideration, in particular if the expected bleeding complications are small in relation to the expected benefit of thrombolysis.	3.8238342255030484
Since acute-PTCA has been shown to remarkably reduce mortality in patients with cardiogenic shock after acute myocardial infarction, this group of patients should be especially considered.	4.4505083719429415
